Statue of Liberty.passage: The Statue of Liberty is a colossal neoclassical sculpture on Liberty Island in New York Harbor within New York City, in the United States. The copper statue, a gift from the people of France to the people of the United States, was designed by French sculptor Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi and its metal framework was built by Gustave Eiffel. The statue was dedicated on October 28, 1886. The statue is of a woman holding a torch in her right hand and a tablet in her left hand, upon which is inscribed the date of the American Declaration of Independence. A broken chain lies at her feet. The statue is an icon of freedom and of the United States, and was a welcoming sight to immigrants arriving from abroad. The statue is made of copper sheets, which are supported by an iron framework. The statue stands 151 feet (46 meters) tall, but with its pedestal and foundation, it reaches a height of 305 feet (93 meters). The statue weighs 225 tons (204 metric tons) and is made up of 300 copper sheets, each about 3/32 of an inch (2.4 millimeters) thick. The statue was shipped to the United States in crates and assembled on its pedestal on what was then called Bedloe's Island. The pedestal was designed by American architect Richard Morris Hunt. The statue was dedicated on October 28, 1886, in a ceremony presided over by President Grover Cleveland. The statue has undergone several restorations over the years, including a major restoration in the 1980s. The statue was closed to visitors for several years after the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, but reopened in 2004 with increased security measures. Today, the Statue of Liberty is one of the most popular tourist attractions in the United States, with millions of visitors each year. Visitors can climb to the top of the pedestal and take an elevator or stairs to the top of the statue's crown, where they can enjoy panoramic views of New York City and the harbor.

Disneyland.passage: Disneyland is a theme park located in Anaheim, California. It was opened on July 17, 1955, by Walt Disney, and it is the only theme park designed and built under the direct supervision of Walt Disney himself. Disneyland is one of the most popular tourist destinations in the world, attracting millions of visitors each year. The park is divided into eight themed lands, each with its own unique attractions, restaurants, and shops. These lands include Main Street, U.S.A., Adventureland, Frontierland, Fantasyland, Tomorrowland, New Orleans Square, Critter Country, and Mickey's Toontown. Main Street, U.S.A. is designed to resemble a small American town at the turn of the 20th century. It features shops, restaurants, and attractions that reflect this time period, such as the Main Street Cinema and the Disneyland Railroad. Adventureland is themed after exotic locations around the world, such as Africa, Asia, and the South Pacific. It features attractions such as the Jungle Cruise, Indiana Jones Adventure, and the Enchanted Tiki Room. Frontierland is designed to resemble the American frontier of the 19th century. It features attractions such as Big Thunder Mountain Railroad, Frontierland Shootin' Exposition, and the Mark Twain Riverboat. Fantasyland is designed to resemble a fairy tale village, and it features attractions such as Sleeping Beauty Castle, Peter Pan's Flight, and It's a Small World. Tomorrowland is designed to represent the future, and it features attractions such as Space Mountain, Star Tours, and Buzz Lightyear Astro Blasters. New Orleans Square is designed to resemble the French Quarter of New Orleans, and it features attractions such as Pirates of the Caribbean and the Haunted Mansion. Critter Country is themed after the wilderness, and it features attractions such as Splash Mountain and the Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh. Mickey's Toontown is designed to resemble the cartoon world of Mickey Mouse and his friends, and it features attractions such as Roger Rabbit's Car Toon Spin and Gadget's Go Coaster. In addition to these themed lands, Disneyland also features parades, fireworks shows, and live entertainment throughout the day. The park is also home to several hotels, restaurants, and shopping areas, making it a complete vacation destination. Overall, Disneyland is a beloved theme park that has captured the hearts of millions of visitors over the years. Its unique blend of nostalgia, fantasy, and innovation has made it a true icon of American culture.

Eiffel Tower.passage: The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower on the Champ de Mars in Paris, France. It is named after the engineer Gustave Eiffel, whose company designed and built the tower. Constructed from 1887 to 1889 as the entrance to the 1889 World's Fair, it was initially criticized by some of France's leading artists and intellectuals for its design, but it has become a global cultural icon of France and one of the most recognizable structures in the world. The Eiffel Tower is the most-visited paid monument in the world; 6.91 million people ascended it in 2015. The tower is 324 metres (1,063 ft) tall, about the same height as an 81-storey building, and the tallest structure in Paris. Its base is square, measuring 125 metres (410 ft) on each side. During its construction, the Eiffel Tower surpassed the Washington Monument to become the tallest man-made structure in the world, a title it held for 41 years until the Chrysler Building in New York City was finished in 1930. Due to the addition of a broadcasting aerial at the top of the tower in 1957, it is now taller than the Chrysler Building by 5.2 metres (17 ft). Excluding transmitters, the Eiffel Tower is the second tallest free-standing structure in France after the Millau Viaduct. The tower has three levels for visitors, with restaurants on the first and second levels. The top level's upper platform is 276 m (906 ft) above the ground – the highest observation deck accessible to the public in the European Union. Tickets can be purchased to ascend by stairs or lift (elevator) to the first and second levels. The climb from ground level to the first level is over 300 steps, as is the climb from the first to the second level. Although there are stairs to the third and highest level, these are usually closed to the public and it is generally only accessible by lift. The design of the Eiffel Tower is attributed to Maurice Koechlin and Émile Nouguier, two senior engineers who worked for the Compagnie des Établissements Eiffel. The inspiration for the design came from the Latting Observatory, a 50-foot (15 m) tower built in New York City in 1853.

Great Barrier Reef.passage: The Great Barrier Reef is the world's largest coral reef system composed of over 2,900 individual reefs and 900 islands stretching for over 2,300 kilometres (1,400 mi) over an area of approximately 344,400 square kilometres (133,000 sq mi). The reef is located in the Coral Sea, off the coast of Queensland, Australia. The Great Barrier Reef is home to an abundance of marine life, including over 1,500 species of fish, 600 species of coral, and numerous species of sharks, dolphins, turtles, and whales. It is also home to the world's largest population of dugongs, a marine mammal similar to a manatee. The reef was formed over millions of years by the accumulation of coral polyps, tiny animals that secrete a hard calcium carbonate skeleton. The reef is constantly evolving, with new coral growth and the erosion of older coral structures. The Great Barrier Reef is a popular tourist destination, attracting millions of visitors each year. Activities such as snorkelling, scuba diving, and glass-bottom boat tours allow visitors to experience the beauty and diversity of the reef up close. However, the reef is also facing numerous threats, including climate change, pollution, and overfishing. Rising sea temperatures and ocean acidification are causing coral bleaching, a process in which coral expels the algae that live within its tissues, leading to the death of the coral. Pollution from agricultural runoff and coastal development can also harm the reef, while overfishing can disrupt the delicate balance of the ecosystem. Efforts are being made to protect the Great Barrier Reef, including the establishment of marine protected areas and the implementation of sustainable fishing practices. However, the future of the reef remains uncertain, and continued action is needed to ensure its survival for future generations.

Grand Canyon.passage: The Grand Canyon is a steep-sided canyon carved by the Colorado River in Arizona, United States. The Grand Canyon is 277 miles (446 km) long, up to 18 miles (29 km) wide and attains a depth of over a mile (6,093 feet or 1,857 meters). The canyon and adjacent rim are contained within Grand Canyon National Park, the Kaibab National Forest, Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument, the Hualapai Indian Reservation, the Havasupai Indian Reservation and the Navajo Nation. President Theodore Roosevelt was a major proponent of preservation of the Grand Canyon area and visited it on numerous occasions to hunt and enjoy the scenery. The Grand Canyon is a massive geological feature, and its geology is well studied and understood. The canyon was created by the Colorado River cutting a channel over millions of years, and is one of the most studied geologic landscapes in the world. The layers of rock exposed in the canyon provide a record of geologic events that span much of the Earth's history. The majority of the rocks in the Grand Canyon are sedimentary rocks, with the oldest dating back to the Precambrian period, over 1.7 billion years ago. The Grand Canyon is a popular tourist destination, attracting millions of visitors each year. The South Rim of the Grand Canyon is the most accessible and most visited part of the canyon, with numerous viewpoints and trails for visitors to explore. The North Rim of the Grand Canyon is less accessible and less visited, but offers a more remote and rugged experience for those willing to make the journey. The Grand Canyon is also a popular destination for hiking, backpacking, rafting, and other outdoor activities. The Grand Canyon is also home to a diverse array of plant and animal life, with over 1,500 plant species and over 400 animal species found within the park. The park is home to several endangered species, including the California condor, humpback chub, and razorback sucker. The Grand Canyon is also an important cultural site for several Native American tribes, including the Havasupai, Hualapai, Navajo, and Hopi. Overall, the Grand Canyon is a unique and awe-inspiring natural wonder, with a rich geological history, diverse plant and animal life, and important cultural significance. It is a testament to the power and beauty of nature, and a reminder of the importance of preserving our natural heritage for future generations.

Niagara Falls.passage: Niagara Falls is a group of three waterfalls located on the Niagara River, which flows from Lake Erie to Lake Ontario. The falls are located on the international border between the United States and Canada, with the American Falls and Bridal Veil Falls located in New York and the Horseshoe Falls located in Ontario, Canada. The Horseshoe Falls, also known as the Canadian Falls, is the largest of the three falls, measuring approximately 2,600 feet wide and 167 feet high. The American Falls and Bridal Veil Falls are smaller, measuring approximately 1,060 feet wide and 176 feet high. Niagara Falls is a popular tourist destination, attracting millions of visitors each year. Visitors can view the falls from various vantage points, including observation decks, boat tours, and helicopter rides. The falls are also illuminated at night, creating a stunning visual display. In addition to its natural beauty, Niagara Falls has a rich history. The falls have been a source of inspiration for artists and writers, and have played a significant role in the development of the surrounding area. The falls have also been the site of several notable events, including tightrope walks and barrel rides. Despite its popularity, Niagara Falls is also a source of controversy. The falls are a major source of hydroelectric power, and there have been debates over the environmental impact of this usage. Additionally, there have been concerns over the preservation of the falls and the surrounding area. Overall, Niagara Falls is a natural wonder that continues to captivate visitors from around the world. Its beauty and power are a testament to the awe-inspiring forces of nature.

Machu Picchu.passage: Machu Picchu is a 15th-century Inca citadel, located in the Eastern Cordillera of southern Peru, on a 2,430-metre (7,970 ft) mountain ridge. It is located in the Cusco Region, Urubamba Province, Machupicchu District, above the Sacred Valley, which is 80 kilometres (50 mi) northwest of Cuzco and through which the Urubamba River flows, cutting through the Cordillera and creating a canyon with a tropical mountain climate. Most archaeologists believe that Machu Picchu was built as an estate for the Inca emperor Pachacuti (1438–1472). Often mistakenly referred to as the "Lost City of the Incas" (a title more accurately applied to Vilcabamba), it is the most familiar icon of Inca civilization. The Incas built the estate around 1450 but abandoned it a century later at the time of the Spanish Conquest. Although known locally, it was not known to the Spanish during the colonial period and remained unknown to the outside world until American historian Hiram Bingham brought it to international attention in 1911. Machu Picchu was built in the classical Inca style, with polished dry-stone walls. Its three primary structures are the Inti Watana, the Temple of the Sun, and the Room of the Three Windows. Most of the outlying buildings have been reconstructed in order to give tourists a better idea of how they originally appeared. By 1976, thirty percent of Machu Picchu had been restored and restoration continues. Machu Picchu was declared a Peruvian Historical Sanctuary in 1981 and a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1983. In 2007, Machu Picchu was voted one of the New Seven Wonders of the World in a worldwide Internet poll.

Taj Mahal.passage: The Taj Mahal is an ivory-white marble mausoleum on the right bank of the Yamuna river in the Indian city of Agra. It was commissioned in 1632 by the Mughal emperor, Shah Jahan, to house the tomb of his favorite wife, Mumtaz Mahal. The Taj Mahal is widely considered to be one of the most beautiful buildings in the world and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The construction of the Taj Mahal took over 20 years and involved the work of thousands of artisans and craftsmen. The marble used in the construction was brought from Rajasthan and the precious stones used in the inlay work were sourced from all over the world. The design of the Taj Mahal is a blend of Islamic, Persian, and Indian architectural styles. The main structure of the Taj Mahal is a large dome, which is surrounded by four smaller domes. The dome is made of white marble and is decorated with intricate carvings and inlay work. The main entrance to the Taj Mahal is through a large gate, which is also made of white marble and is decorated with calligraphy and floral designs. Inside the Taj Mahal, there are two tombs, one for Mumtaz Mahal and one for Shah Jahan. The tombs are made of white marble and are decorated with precious stones and intricate carvings. The walls of the Taj Mahal are also decorated with intricate carvings and inlay work, which depict scenes from the Quran and other Islamic texts. The Taj Mahal is surrounded by a large garden, which is divided into four parts by water channels. The garden is designed in the Persian style and is meant to represent paradise. The garden is also home to several fountains and pavilions, which provide shade and a place to rest. Today, the Taj Mahal is one of the most popular tourist attractions in India and attracts millions of visitors every year. It is also considered to be one of the most romantic buildings in the world and is a popular destination for couples. The Taj Mahal is a symbol of love and devotion and is a testament to the beauty and skill of the artisans and craftsmen who built it.

Sydney Opera House.passage: The Sydney Opera House is a multi-venue performing arts center in Sydney, New South Wales, Australia. It is one of the 20th century's most famous and distinctive buildings. Designed by Danish architect Jørn Utzon, the building was formally opened on 20 October 1973 after a gestation beginning with Utzon's 1957 selection as winner of an international design competition. The Government of New South Wales, led by the premier, Joseph Cahill, authorised work to begin in 1958 with Utzon directing construction. The government's decision to build Utzon's design is often overshadowed by circumstances that followed, including cost and scheduling overruns as well as the architect's ultimate resignation. The building and its surrounds occupy the whole of Bennelong Point in Sydney Harbour, between Sydney Cove and Farm Cove, adjacent to the Sydney central business district and the Royal Botanic Garden, and close by the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Though its name suggests a single venue, the building comprises multiple performance venues which together are among the busiest performing arts centres in the world — hosting well over 1,500 performances annually, attended by more than 1.2 million people. Performances are presented by numerous performing artists, including three resident companies: Opera Australia, the Sydney Theatre Company and the Sydney Symphony Orchestra. As one of the most popular visitor attractions in Australia, the site is visited by more than eight million people annually, and approximately 350,000 visitors take a guided tour of the building each year. The building is managed by the Sydney Opera House Trust, an agency of the New South Wales State Government. On 28 June 2007, the Sydney Opera House became a UNESCO World Heritage Site, having been listed on the (now defunct) Register of the National Estate since 1980, the National Trust of Australia register since 1983, the City of Sydney Heritage Inventory since 2000, the New South Wales State Heritage Register since 2003, and the Australian National Heritage List since 2005. The building is also on the Australian National Heritage List and the New South Wales State Heritage Register.

Yellowstone National Park.passage: Yellowstone National Park is a national park located primarily in the U.S. state of Wyoming, although it also extends into Montana and Idaho. It was established by the U.S. Congress and signed into law by President Ulysses S. Grant on March 1, 1872. Yellowstone was the first national park in the U.S. and is widely considered to be the first national park in the world. The park spans an area of 2.2 million acres and is home to a diverse range of wildlife, including grizzly bears, wolves, bison, and elk. It also contains the largest concentration of geysers in the world, with over 500 geysers and hot springs. The most famous of these is Old Faithful, which erupts approximately every 90 minutes. Yellowstone is situated on top of a supervolcano, which has erupted three times in the past 2.1 million years. The most recent eruption occurred approximately 640,000 years ago and created the Yellowstone Caldera, which is a massive crater that measures approximately 30 by 45 miles. The park is also home to a number of other geological features, including the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone, which is a 20-mile-long canyon that is up to 4,000 feet deep. The canyon is carved by the Yellowstone River and is known for its stunning waterfalls and colorful rock formations. Yellowstone is a popular destination for tourists, with over 4 million visitors each year. The park offers a wide range of activities, including hiking, camping, fishing, and wildlife watching. It also has a number of historic lodges and cabins that offer visitors a unique and authentic experience. In addition to its natural beauty, Yellowstone is also an important site for scientific research. The park is home to a number of research facilities and is a popular destination for scientists studying geology, ecology, and wildlife biology. Overall, Yellowstone National Park is a unique and important natural resource that offers visitors a glimpse into the natural wonders of the world. Its stunning landscapes, diverse wildlife, and geological features make it a must-see destination for anyone interested in the natural world.

Burj Khalifa.passage: Burj Khalifa, also known as the Khalifa Tower, is a skyscraper located in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. It is the tallest building in the world, standing at a height of 828 meters (2,716 feet). The tower was designed by Adrian Smith, of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, and was constructed by South Korean company Samsung C&T. The building was officially opened on January 4, 2010, and is named after the President of the United Arab Emirates, Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan. The construction of Burj Khalifa began in 2004, and it took six years to complete. The tower has 163 floors, with the highest occupied floor being on the 154th floor. The building has a total of 57 elevators and eight escalators, and it is capable of accommodating up to 35,000 people at any given time. The tower is made up of three sections: the central core, the wings, and the spire. The central core houses the elevators, stairwells, and mechanical systems, while the wings contain the residential and office spaces. The spire, which is made up of steel and aluminum, is located at the top of the tower and serves as a beacon for the building. Burj Khalifa has a number of world records to its name. It is the tallest building in the world, the tallest free-standing structure in the world, and the building with the highest number of floors in the world. It also has the highest outdoor observation deck in the world, located on the 148th floor, and the fastest elevators in the world, which can travel at a speed of 10 meters per second. The tower has a number of uses, including residential, commercial, and hotel space. The Armani Hotel Dubai is located in the tower, as well as a number of high-end restaurants and retail spaces. The tower also has a number of outdoor spaces, including the Burj Khalifa Park, which is located at the base of the tower. Burj Khalifa has become an iconic symbol of Dubai and the United Arab Emirates. It has been featured in a number of films and television shows, and has become a popular tourist attraction. The tower has also been recognized for its sustainable design, with features such as a condensate collection system and a high-performance exterior façade.

Acropolis of Athens.passage: The Acropolis of Athens is an ancient citadel located on a rocky outcrop above the city of Athens and contains the remains of several ancient buildings of great architectural and historic significance, the most famous being the Parthenon. The word acropolis is derived from the Greek words ἄκρον (akron, "highest point, extremity") and πόλις (polis, "city"). Although the term acropolis is generic and there are many other acropoleis in Greece, the significance of the Acropolis of Athens is such that it is commonly known as "The Acropolis" without qualification. The Acropolis was formally proclaimed as the preeminent monument on the European Cultural Heritage list of monuments on 26 March 2007. The Acropolis is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, the first such site in Greece, inscribed in 1987. The Acropolis is also a significant archaeological site and a major tourist attraction. Almost every visitor to Athens visits the Acropolis hill, which is visible from almost everywhere in the city. The Acropolis of Athens is located on a rocky outcrop above the city of Athens, with a height of about 150 meters (490 ft). The outcrop is surrounded by a natural amphitheatre of hills, which provides a natural defence for the citadel. The Acropolis is composed of several ancient buildings, the most famous of which is the Parthenon, a temple dedicated to the goddess Athena. Other notable buildings on the Acropolis include the Propylaea, the Erechtheion, and the Temple of Athena Nike. The history of the Acropolis of Athens dates back to the Neolithic period, but the most significant period of construction and development occurred during the 5th century BC, when Athens was at the height of its power and influence. During this period, the Acropolis was transformed into a monumental complex of temples, sanctuaries, and public buildings, which served as the religious and cultural centre of Athens. The Acropolis of Athens has undergone many changes and renovations over the centuries, including damage caused by wars, earthquakes, and looting. The most significant restoration project was carried out in the 20th century, under the direction of the Greek architect Nikolaos Balanos. The restoration work included the removal of later additions and alterations, the replacement of missing or damaged parts, and the reinforcement of the structures to ensure their stability.

qae_pairs.context: The Acropolis of Athens is an ancient citadel located on a rocky outcrop above the city of Athens and contains the remains of several ancient buildings of great architectural and historic significance, the most famous being the Parthenon. The word acropolis is derived from the Greek words ἄκρον (akron, "highest point, extremity") and πόλις (polis, "city").
qae_pairs.question: What is the most famous building located on the Acropolis of Athens?

Stonehenge.passage: Stonehenge is a prehistoric monument located in Wiltshire, England. It is composed of a ring of standing stones, each weighing around 25 tons, and is surrounded by a circular ditch and bank. The monument is believed to have been constructed between 3000 and 2000 BCE, during the Neolithic period. The purpose of Stonehenge is still a subject of debate among archaeologists and historians. Some believe it was a place of worship or a site for astronomical observation, while others suggest it was a burial ground or a place for healing. The monument's alignment with the solstices and equinoxes has led some to believe it was used as a calendar or for tracking the seasons. Stonehenge has undergone several phases of construction and modification over the centuries. The first phase, which began around 3000 BCE, involved the digging of a circular ditch and bank. The stones were erected in the second phase, which began around 2500 BCE. The stones were transported from quarries in Wales, over 150 miles away, and erected using a system of ropes, levers, and pulleys. The third phase, which began around 2100 BCE, involved the rearrangement of the stones into their current configuration. The monument was used for several centuries before falling into disuse around 1600 BCE. It was rediscovered in the 17th century and has since become one of the most famous and iconic landmarks in the world. Stonehenge has been the subject of much speculation and fascination over the centuries. It has been the inspiration for countless works of art, literature, and music, and has been the site of many rituals and ceremonies. Today, it is a popular tourist attraction and a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Tower Bridge.passage: Tower Bridge is a combined bascule and suspension bridge in London, built between 1886 and 1894. The bridge crosses the River Thames close to the Tower of London and has become an iconic symbol of London. Tower Bridge is one of five London bridges now owned and maintained by the Bridge House Estates, a charitable trust overseen by the City of London Corporation. The bridge consists of two towers tied together at the upper level by means of two horizontal walkways, designed to withstand the horizontal forces exerted by the suspended sections of the bridge on the landward sides of the towers. The vertical components of the forces in the suspended sections and the vertical reactions of the two walkways are carried by the two robust towers. The bascule pivots and operating machinery are housed in the base of each tower. The bridge's present colour scheme dates from 1977, when it was painted red, white and blue for Queen Elizabeth II's Silver Jubilee. Originally it was painted a mid-greenish blue colour. The bridge deck is freely accessible to both vehicles and pedestrians, whereas the bridge's twin towers, high-level walkways and Victorian engine rooms form part of the Tower Bridge Exhibition, for which an admission charge is made. The nearest London Underground tube stations are Tower Hill on the Circle and District lines, London Bridge on the Jubilee and Northern lines and Bermondsey on the Jubilee line, and the nearest Docklands Light Railway station is Tower Gateway. The nearest National Rail stations are at Fenchurch Street and London Bridge.

Hawaii Volcanoes National Park.passage: Hawaii Volcanoes National Park is a United States National Park located on the island of Hawaii. The park encompasses two active volcanoes: Kilauea, one of the world's most active volcanoes, and Mauna Loa, the world's most massive subaerial volcano. The park is also home to numerous other volcanic features, including lava tubes, cinder cones, and craters. The park was established in 1916, making it one of the oldest national parks in the United States. It covers an area of 323,431 acres (1,308.88 km2), including the summit of Mauna Loa at 13,677 feet (4,169 m) and the Kilauea Caldera, which is 2.4 miles (3.9 km) wide and 400 feet (120 m) deep. Kilauea has been erupting continuously since 1983, making it one of the most active volcanoes in the world. The eruption has created a constantly changing landscape, with new lava flows and volcanic features appearing regularly. Visitors to the park can witness this dynamic process firsthand, with guided hikes and ranger-led programs available to explore the park's volcanic features. The park is also home to a diverse range of flora and fauna, including endangered species such as the Hawaiian goose (nene) and the Hawaiian bat (hoary bat). The park's unique ecosystem is the result of its location in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, far from any other landmass. In addition to its natural wonders, the park also has a rich cultural history. The park is home to numerous archaeological sites, including petroglyphs and ancient Hawaiian temples (heiau). The park's visitor center features exhibits on the park's geology, ecology, and cultural history, as well as a theater showing films about the park's natural and cultural resources. Overall, Hawaii Volcanoes National Park is a unique and fascinating destination, offering visitors the opportunity to witness the power of nature firsthand and learn about the rich cultural history of the Hawaiian Islands.

Petra.passage: Petra is a historical and archaeological city in southern Jordan. It is famous for its rock-cut architecture and water conduit system. Established possibly as early as 312 BC as the capital city of the Nabataeans, it is a symbol of Jordan, as well as its most visited tourist attraction. It lies on the slope of Jebel al-Madhbah (identified by some as the biblical Mount Hor) in a basin among the mountains which form the eastern flank of Arabah (Wadi Araba), the large valley running from the Dead Sea to the Gulf of Aqaba. Petra has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1985. The site remained unknown to the Western world until 1812, when it was introduced by Swiss explorer Johann Ludwig Burckhardt. It was described as "a rose-red city half as old as time" in a Newdigate Prize-winning poem by John William Burgon. UNESCO has described it as "one of the most precious cultural properties of man's cultural heritage". Petra was named amongst the New7Wonders of the World in 2007 and was also chosen by the Smithsonian Magazine as one of the "28 Places to See Before You Die". Petra is a symbol of Jordan, as well as its most visited tourist attraction. Tourist numbers peaked at 1 million in 2010, but had fallen to around 200,000 by 2019 due to regional instability. However, tourist numbers have been recovering since 2020. The site was closed to tourists for several months in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Nabataeans were nomadic Arabs who took advantage of Petra's proximity to regional trade routes to establish it as a major trading hub. The Nabataeans are also known for their great ability in constructing efficient water-collecting methods in the barren deserts and their talent in carving structures into solid rocks. The Colosseum.passage: The Colosseum, also known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an oval amphitheatre in the center of Rome, Italy. It is considered one of the greatest works of Roman architecture and engineering. The Colosseum was built between 70-80 AD and was commissioned by Emperor Vespasian of the Flavian dynasty as a gift to the Roman people. It was completed by his son, Emperor Titus, in 80 AD. The Colosseum was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles such as animal hunts, mock sea battles, and executions. It could hold up to 80,000 spectators and was the largest amphitheatre in the Roman Empire. The Colosseum was also used for religious ceremonies and was considered a symbol of the power and wealth of Rome. The Colosseum is made of concrete and stone and is 189 meters long, 156 meters wide, and 50 meters high. It has four levels, with the lower two levels made of travertine stone and the upper two levels made of tufa and brick. The Colosseum was designed to be easily accessible, with 80 entrances and exits. The Colosseum was damaged by earthquakes and looting over the centuries, but it has been partially restored and is now a popular tourist attraction. It is also a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is considered one of the Seven Wonders of the World. The Colosseum has been the subject of many works of art and literature, including the film Gladiator. It has also been used as a symbol of political and social issues, such as the fight against animal cruelty and the struggle for LGBTQ+ rights. Today, the Colosseum is a popular tourist attraction and is visited by millions of people each year. It is also used for cultural events and concerts. The Colosseum remains a symbol of the power and grandeur of ancient Rome and is a testament to the ingenuity and skill of Roman engineering.

Angkor Wat.passage: Angkor Wat is a temple complex in Cambodia and the largest religious monument in the world. It was originally built as a Hindu temple in the early 12th century, but gradually transformed into a Buddhist temple by the end of the century. The temple was built by the Khmer King Suryavarman II as his state temple and capital city. It is located in the province of Siem Reap and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The temple complex covers an area of 162.6 hectares and is surrounded by a moat that is 190 meters wide. The central temple is surrounded by a series of smaller temples and shrines, as well as a number of reservoirs and canals. The temple is built in the classical Khmer style, with five towers representing the five peaks of Mount Meru, the home of the gods in Hindu mythology. The temple is known for its intricate carvings and bas-reliefs, which depict scenes from Hindu mythology and the life of the Khmer people. The carvings cover almost every surface of the temple, including the walls, columns, and ceilings. The most famous of these carvings is the Churning of the Ocean of Milk, which depicts the gods and demons churning the ocean to create the elixir of immortality. The temple was abandoned in the 15th century and fell into disrepair. It was rediscovered in the 19th century by French explorers and has since been restored and preserved. Today, Angkor Wat is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Southeast Asia, attracting millions of visitors each year. Despite its popularity, the temple complex faces a number of challenges, including overcrowding, erosion, and damage from tourism. The Cambodian government and international organizations are working to address these issues and ensure the long-term preservation of this important cultural site.

Mount Everest.passage: Mount Everest, also known as Sagarmatha in Nepali and Chomolungma in Tibetan, is the highest mountain in the world, standing at 8,848 meters (29,029 feet) above sea level. It is located in the Mahalangur Himal sub-range of the Himalayas, on the border between Nepal and Tibet. The first recorded attempt to climb Mount Everest was made in 1921 by a British expedition led by George Mallory. However, it was not until 1953 that the mountain was successfully climbed by Sir Edmund Hillary of New Zealand and Tenzing Norgay, a Sherpa of Nepal. Since then, thousands of climbers have attempted to reach the summit, with varying degrees of success. The climb to the summit of Mount Everest is considered one of the most challenging and dangerous mountaineering feats in the world. The extreme altitude, unpredictable weather conditions, and difficult terrain make it a formidable challenge for even the most experienced climbers. The climb typically takes several weeks, with climbers acclimatizing to the altitude and weather conditions before making their final push to the summit. Despite the risks, the allure of Mount Everest continues to draw climbers from around the world. In recent years, there has been controversy surrounding the commercialization of the mountain, with concerns about overcrowding, environmental damage, and the safety of climbers. Nevertheless, Mount Everest remains a symbol of human achievement and a testament to the power of the human spirit to overcome seemingly insurmountable challenges.

Victoria Falls.passage: Victoria Falls is a waterfall located in southern Africa on the Zambezi River at the border between Zambia and Zimbabwe. It is considered one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The falls are named after Queen Victoria, who was the reigning monarch of the United Kingdom at the time of their discovery in 1855 by Scottish explorer David Livingstone. The falls are approximately 1.7 kilometers wide and 108 meters high, making them the largest waterfall in the world in terms of the combined width and height of the falls. The water falls into a narrow gorge, which is up to 110 meters deep and 1.6 kilometers wide. The spray from the falls can be seen from up to 50 kilometers away and creates a permanent rainforest in the surrounding area. The falls are known locally as Mosi-oa-Tunya, which means "the smoke that thunders." This name refers to the mist and noise created by the falling water, which can be heard from several kilometers away. The falls are a popular tourist destination and attract visitors from all over the world. There are several viewpoints from which visitors can view the falls, including the Devil's Pool, which is a natural pool located at the edge of the falls. Visitors can swim in the pool and look over the edge of the falls, but it is only accessible during the dry season when the water level is low. The falls are also a popular destination for adventure activities such as bungee jumping, white-water rafting, and helicopter tours. The surrounding area is home to a variety of wildlife, including elephants, buffalo, and hippos. The falls are fed by the Zambezi River, which flows through six countries before reaching the falls. The flow of water over the falls varies throughout the year, with the highest flow occurring during the rainy season from November to April. Despite their beauty, the falls have a dark history. The area was once home to the Makololo people, who were displaced by the arrival of European settlers in the 19th century. The falls were also the site of several battles during the colonial era, including the Battle of Livingstone in 1895. Today, the falls are a symbol of the natural beauty and cultural heritage of southern Africa. They continue to attract visitors from all over the world and are a testament to the power and majesty of nature.

Antarctica Cruise.passage: Antarctica Cruise refers to a type of cruise that takes passengers to the continent of Antarctica. These cruises typically depart from ports in South America, such as Ushuaia in Argentina or Punta Arenas in Chile, and can last anywhere from 10 days to several weeks. Antarctica cruises offer passengers the opportunity to explore one of the most remote and pristine regions on Earth. The continent is home to a diverse array of wildlife, including penguins, seals, and whales, as well as stunning landscapes of icebergs, glaciers, and snow-covered mountains. Most Antarctica cruises include stops at several locations along the Antarctic Peninsula, which is the northernmost part of the continent and the most accessible for tourists. Some cruises also visit the South Shetland Islands, which are located just off the coast of the peninsula. Passengers on Antarctica cruises can participate in a variety of activities, including shore excursions to visit penguin colonies and research stations, kayaking and paddleboarding in the icy waters, and even camping on the continent itself. Many cruises also offer lectures and presentations by experts in Antarctic history, geology, and wildlife. Antarctica cruises are typically operated by small expedition ships, which are designed to navigate the icy waters and provide passengers with a comfortable and safe experience. These ships typically carry between 50 and 200 passengers, and offer amenities such as comfortable cabins, dining rooms, and lounges. Due to the remote and challenging nature of Antarctica, these cruises can be expensive and require careful planning. Passengers must be prepared for cold and unpredictable weather conditions, and must follow strict guidelines to protect the fragile environment of the continent. Despite these challenges, Antarctica cruises are a once-in-a-lifetime experience for many travelers, offering a unique opportunity to explore one of the most pristine and untouched regions on Earth.

Sahara Desert Safari.passage: The Sahara Desert Safari is a popular tourist activity that takes place in the Sahara Desert, the largest hot desert in the world. The safari offers visitors a chance to explore the vast expanse of the desert, which covers over 3.6 million square miles across North Africa. The Sahara Desert Safari typically involves a guided tour that takes visitors through the desert on a 4x4 vehicle or on the back of a camel. The tour usually lasts for several days and includes stops at various points of interest, such as ancient ruins, oases, and traditional Berber villages. During the safari, visitors can experience the unique landscape of the Sahara, which is characterized by sand dunes, rocky outcrops, and vast stretches of barren land. They can also witness the stunning sunsets and sunrises that the desert is famous for, as well as the clear night skies that offer a perfect view of the stars. One of the highlights of the Sahara Desert Safari is the opportunity to interact with the local Berber people, who have lived in the desert for centuries. Visitors can learn about their culture, traditions, and way of life, and even participate in activities such as cooking traditional meals and making handicrafts. The Sahara Desert Safari is also a great way to experience the thrill of adventure, as visitors can engage in activities such as sandboarding, quad biking, and dune bashing. These activities offer a unique and exciting way to explore the desert and create unforgettable memories. Overall, the Sahara Desert Safari is a must-do activity for anyone visiting North Africa. It offers a unique and unforgettable experience that combines adventure, culture, and natural beauty, and is sure to leave visitors with memories that will last a lifetime.

Chichen Itza.passage: Chichen Itza is a pre-Columbian archaeological site located in the Yucatan Peninsula, Mexico. It was a major center of the Maya civilization and is considered one of the most important archaeological sites in Mexico. The site covers an area of approximately 6.5 square kilometers and contains a variety of architectural styles, including the famous El Castillo pyramid. The site was first inhabited by the Maya people around 750 AD, but it was not until the 10th century that Chichen Itza became a major political and economic center. The city was ruled by a series of powerful kings, who oversaw the construction of many of the site's most impressive structures. One of the most famous structures at Chichen Itza is the El Castillo pyramid, also known as the Temple of Kukulcan. This impressive structure stands 30 meters tall and is made up of nine levels, each representing a different level of the Mayan underworld. The pyramid is also famous for its unique design, which includes four staircases, each with 91 steps, and a platform at the top. Another notable structure at Chichen Itza is the Temple of the Warriors, which is located near the El Castillo pyramid. This temple is decorated with a variety of intricate carvings and sculptures, including depictions of warriors and jaguars. The temple is also home to a large plaza, which was used for a variety of ceremonial purposes. Chichen Itza is also home to a number of other impressive structures, including the Great Ball Court, which is the largest ball court in Mesoamerica. This court measures 168 meters long and 70 meters wide and was used for a variety of games and ceremonies. In addition to its impressive architecture, Chichen Itza is also known for its astronomical observatory, which was used by the Maya to study the movements of the stars and planets. The observatory is made up of a circular tower and a series of chambers, which were used to track the movements of celestial bodies. Today, Chichen Itza is a popular tourist destination and is visited by millions of people each year. The site has been designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is considered one of the most important archaeological sites in the world.

Galapagos Islands.passage: The Galápagos Islands (official name: Archipiélago de Colón, other Spanish name: Islas Galápagos, Spanish pronunciation: [ˈislas gaˈlapaɣos]) are an archipelago of volcanic islands distributed on either side of the Equator in the Pacific Ocean, 906 km (563 mi) west of continental Ecuador. The islands are known for their large number of endemic species and were studied by Charles Darwin during the second voyage of HMS Beagle. His observations and collections contributed to the inception of Darwin's theory of evolution by means of natural selection. The Galápagos Islands and their surrounding waters form the Galápagos Province of Ecuador, the Galápagos National Park, and the Galápagos Marine Reserve. The principal language on the islands is Spanish. The islands have a population of slightly over 25,000. The first recorded visit to the islands happened by chance in 1535, when the Bishop of Panamá Fray Tomás de Berlanga went to Peru to settle a dispute between Francisco Pizarro and his lieutenants. De Berlanga was blown off course, though he eventually returned to the Spanish Empire and described the conditions of the islands and the giant tortoises that inhabited them. The group of islands was shown and named in Abraham Ortelius's atlas published in 1570. The first crude map of the islands was made in 1684 by the buccaneer Ambrose Cowley, who named the individual islands after some of his fellow pirates or after the English noblemen who helped the privateer's cause. These names were used in the authoritative navigation charts of the islands prepared during the Beagle survey under captain Robert Fitzroy, and in Darwin's popular book The Voyage of the Beagle. The new Republic of Ecuador took the islands from Spanish ownership in 1832, and subsequently gave them official Spanish names. The older names remained in use in English language publications, including Herman Melville's The Encantadas of 1854. The islands are located at the Galápagos Triple Junction. The archipelago consists of 18 main islands, 3 smaller islands, and 107 rocks and islets. The islands are located at the eastern Pacific Ocean, 973 km (605 mi) off the west coast of South America.

Mount Kilimanjaro..passage: Mount Kilimanjaro is a dormant volcanic mountain in Tanzania, Africa. It is the highest peak in Africa, standing at 5,895 meters (19,341 feet) above sea level. The mountain is composed of three distinct volcanic cones: Kibo, Mawenzi, and Shira. Kibo is the highest and most well-known of the three, and is the only one that is currently dormant. Mount Kilimanjaro is a popular destination for hikers and climbers, attracting thousands of visitors each year. The mountain is located in Kilimanjaro National Park, which was established in 1973 to protect the area's unique flora and fauna. The park covers an area of 1,688 square kilometers (652 square miles) and is home to a variety of wildlife, including elephants, leopards, and buffalo. The first recorded ascent of Mount Kilimanjaro was in 1889 by German geographer Hans Meyer and Austrian mountaineer Ludwig Purtscheller. Since then, the mountain has become a popular destination for climbers from all over the world. The climb to the summit is not technically difficult, but it is physically demanding and requires a good level of fitness. There are several routes to the summit of Mount Kilimanjaro, each with its own unique features and challenges. The most popular routes are the Marangu, Machame, and Lemosho routes. The Marangu route is the easiest and most direct, while the Machame and Lemosho routes are more challenging but offer more scenic views. The climate on Mount Kilimanjaro varies depending on the altitude. At the base of the mountain, the climate is tropical, with temperatures ranging from 20 to 30 degrees Celsius (68 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit). As climbers ascend the mountain, the temperature drops and the climate becomes more arid. At the summit, temperatures can drop to as low as -20 degrees Celsius (-4 degrees Fahrenheit). Mount Kilimanjaro is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is considered one of the Seven Natural Wonders of Africa. It is also an important source of water for the surrounding communities, providing water for drinking, irrigation, and hydroelectric power. However, the mountain is also facing environmental challenges, including deforestation, soil erosion, and climate change. Overall, Mount Kilimanjaro is a unique and awe-inspiring natural wonder that attracts visitors from all over the world.

The Louvre Museum.passage: The Louvre Museum, located in Paris, France, is one of the world's largest and most famous museums. It is housed in the Louvre Palace, which was originally built as a fortress in the late 12th century. The museum was established in 1793, during the French Revolution, and has since grown to house over 35,000 works of art, including paintings, sculptures, and decorative objects. The Louvre Museum is divided into eight departments, each with its own collection of art. These departments include Egyptian Antiquities, Near Eastern Antiquities, Greek, Etruscan, and Roman Antiquities, Islamic Art, Sculptures, Decorative Arts, Paintings, and Prints and Drawings. The museum's collection includes some of the most famous works of art in the world, such as the Mona Lisa by Leonardo da Vinci, the Winged Victory of Samothrace, and the Venus de Milo. In addition to its permanent collection, the Louvre Museum also hosts temporary exhibitions throughout the year. These exhibitions showcase works of art from around the world and cover a wide range of topics and themes. The Louvre Museum is also known for its iconic glass pyramid, which was designed by architect I.M. Pei and completed in 1989. The pyramid serves as the main entrance to the museum and has become a symbol of the Louvre and Paris itself. The Louvre Museum is a popular tourist destination, attracting millions of visitors each year. It is open every day except Tuesdays and certain holidays, and offers a variety of guided tours and audio guides to help visitors navigate the vast collection of art. Overall, the Louvre Museum is a must-see destination for anyone interested in art and history. Its collection of works spans thousands of years and represents cultures from around the world, making it one of the most diverse and comprehensive museums in the world.

Central Park.passage: Central Park is an urban park in New York City located between the Upper West and Upper East Sides of Manhattan. It is the fifth-largest park in the city by area, covering 843 acres. The park was designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, who wanted to create a peaceful oasis in the midst of the bustling city. Construction began in 1858 and was completed in 1873. Central Park is home to many attractions, including the Central Park Zoo, the Central Park Conservatory Garden, and the Central Park Carousel. The park also features several lakes and ponds, including the famous Central Park Lake, which is popular for boating and fishing. The park is also home to several sports facilities, including the Central Park Tennis Center, the Central Park Skate Park, and the Central Park Running Track. One of the most iconic features of Central Park is the Great Lawn, a large open space that is used for concerts, picnics, and other events. The Great Lawn is surrounded by trees and is a popular spot for sunbathing and relaxing. Another popular attraction is the Central Park Zoo, which is home to a wide variety of animals, including penguins, sea lions, and snow leopards. Central Park is also home to several monuments and statues, including the Alice in Wonderland statue, the Balto statue, and the Bethesda Fountain. The park is also a popular filming location, with many movies and TV shows being filmed there over the years. Central Park is open year-round and is free to enter. It is a popular destination for tourists and locals alike, offering a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Great Wall of China.passage: The Great Wall of China is a series of fortifications made of stone, brick, tamped earth, wood, and other materials, generally built along an east-to-west line across the historical northern borders of China to protect the Chinese states and empires against the raids and invasions of the various nomadic groups of the Eurasian Steppe. Several walls were being built from as early as the 7th century BC by ancient Chinese states; selective stretches were later joined together by Qin Shi Huang (220–206 BC), the first emperor of China. Little of the Qin wall remains. Later on, many successive dynasties have built and maintained multiple stretches of border walls. The most well-known sections of the wall were built by the Ming dynasty (1368–1644). Apart from defense, other purposes of the Great Wall have included border controls, allowing the imposition of duties on goods transported along the Silk Road, regulation or encouragement of trade and the control of immigration and emigration. Furthermore, the defensive characteristics of the Great Wall were enhanced by the construction of watchtowers, troop barracks, garrison stations, signaling capabilities through the means of smoke or fire, and the fact that the path of the Great Wall also served as a transportation corridor. The Great Wall stretches from Dandong in the east to Lop Lake in the west, along an arc that roughly delineates the southern edge of Inner Mongolia. A comprehensive archaeological survey, using advanced technologies, has concluded that the Ming walls measure 8,850 km (5,500 mi). This is made up of 6,259 km (3,889 mi) sections of actual wall, 359 km (223 mi) of trenches and 2,232 km (1,387 mi) of natural defensive barriers such as hills and rivers. The Great Wall is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and a popular tourist destination. The wall is generally recognized as one of the most impressive architectural feats in history. The Great Wall of China has become a symbol of Chinese civilization, representing its ancient history, culture, and strength.

Tokyo Disneyland.passage: Tokyo Disneyland is a theme park located in Urayasu, Chiba, Japan, near Tokyo. It was the first Disney theme park to be built outside the United States, and it opened on April 15, 1983. The park is owned and operated by the Oriental Land Company, which licenses the Disney characters and themes from The Walt Disney Company. Tokyo Disneyland is divided into seven themed lands: World Bazaar, Adventureland, Westernland, Fantasyland, Tomorrowland, Critter Country, and Toontown. Each land has its own unique attractions, restaurants, and shops. The park also features parades, fireworks shows, and seasonal events throughout the year. One of the most popular attractions at Tokyo Disneyland is Pirates of the Caribbean, which is a boat ride through a pirate-infested Caribbean island. Other popular attractions include Space Mountain, a roller coaster through outer space; It's a Small World, a boat ride through a world of singing dolls; and Big Thunder Mountain Railroad, a roller coaster through a western mining town. Tokyo Disneyland also has several unique attractions that are not found in other Disney parks. These include Pooh's Hunny Hunt, a ride through the world of Winnie the Pooh that uses trackless vehicles and projection technology; Monsters, Inc. Ride & Go Seek, a dark ride through Monstropolis where guests use flashlights to find hidden monsters; and the Enchanted Tiki Room: Stitch Presents "Aloha E Komo Mai! ", a musical show featuring Stitch from Lilo & Stitch. In addition to the attractions, Tokyo Disneyland has a wide variety of restaurants and shops. The park offers a mix of Japanese and American cuisine, as well as snacks and treats unique to the park. The shops sell a variety of Disney merchandise, including souvenirs, clothing, and toys. Tokyo Disneyland is one of the most popular theme parks in the world, attracting millions of visitors each year. It has been praised for its attention to detail, cleanliness, and customer service. The park has also been criticized for its long lines and high prices, but many visitors feel that the experience is worth the cost. Overall, Tokyo Disneyland is a must-visit destination for Disney fans and theme park enthusiasts alike.

The Great Barrier Reef.passage: The Great Barrier Reef is the world's largest coral reef system, located in the Coral Sea, off the coast of Australia. It stretches over 2,300 kilometers (1,400 miles) and covers an area of approximately 344,400 square kilometers (133,000 square miles). The reef is made up of over 2,900 individual reefs and 900 islands, and is home to an incredible diversity of marine life, including over 1,500 species of fish, 600 species of coral, and numerous other species of plants and animals. The Great Barrier Reef is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is considered one of the seven natural wonders of the world. It is also an important economic resource for Australia, generating billions of dollars in tourism revenue each year. However, the reef is facing numerous threats, including climate change, pollution, and overfishing. Climate change is one of the biggest threats to the Great Barrier Reef. Rising sea temperatures and ocean acidification are causing coral bleaching, which occurs when the coral expels the algae that live inside it, turning it white and making it more vulnerable to disease and death. In recent years, the reef has experienced several severe bleaching events, with the most recent occurring in 2020. Pollution is also a major threat to the Great Barrier Reef. Runoff from agriculture, mining, and urban areas can introduce pollutants such as sediment, nutrients, and chemicals into the water, which can harm the coral and other marine life. Overfishing is another concern, as it can disrupt the delicate balance of the ecosystem and lead to the depletion of certain species. Efforts are being made to protect the Great Barrier Reef, including the implementation of marine parks and protected areas, as well as initiatives to reduce pollution and promote sustainable fishing practices. However, more needs to be done to address the root causes of the threats facing the reef, including reducing greenhouse gas emissions and transitioning to a more sustainable economy.

Disney World.passage: Walt Disney World Resort, commonly known as Disney World, is a world-renowned entertainment complex located in Bay Lake and Lake Buena Vista, Florida. It was opened on October 1, 1971, and is owned and operated by The Walt Disney Company. The resort spans over 25,000 acres and is home to four theme parks, two water parks, 27 themed resort hotels, nine non-Disney hotels, several golf courses, a camping resort, and other entertainment venues. The four theme parks at Disney World are Magic Kingdom, Epcot, Disney's Hollywood Studios, and Disney's Animal Kingdom. Magic Kingdom is the most popular park and is known for its iconic Cinderella Castle, classic attractions, and parades. Epcot is divided into two sections: Future World, which showcases technological advancements, and World Showcase, which features pavilions representing different countries. Disney's Hollywood Studios is a movie-themed park that offers attractions based on popular films and TV shows. Disney's Animal Kingdom is a zoological park that features live animals and attractions based on nature and conservation. Disney World's two water parks are Typhoon Lagoon and Blizzard Beach. Typhoon Lagoon is themed around a tropical storm, while Blizzard Beach is themed around a ski resort that has melted. Both parks offer water slides, wave pools, and other water attractions. The resort hotels at Disney World are divided into three categories: Value, Moderate, and Deluxe. The Value resorts are the most affordable and offer basic amenities, while the Deluxe resorts are the most luxurious and offer premium amenities. The Moderate resorts are a middle ground between the two. Disney World also offers several entertainment venues, such as Disney Springs, a shopping and dining district, and ESPN Wide World of Sports Complex, a sports complex that hosts various events and tournaments. Overall, Disney World is a popular vacation destination for families and Disney fans alike. It offers a wide range of attractions and entertainment options that cater to all ages and interests.

Forbidden City.passage: The Forbidden City is a palace complex located in central Beijing, China. It served as the imperial palace for the Ming and Qing dynasties from 1420 to 1912 and is now a major tourist attraction and museum. The complex covers an area of 72 hectares and consists of 980 buildings, including palaces, halls, pavilions, and courtyards. The Forbidden City was built during the Ming dynasty by Emperor Yongle, who moved the capital from Nanjing to Beijing. Construction began in 1406 and was completed in 1420. The palace complex was designed to be the center of the Chinese universe, with the emperor as the Son of Heaven and the ruler of all under heaven. The Forbidden City is surrounded by a moat and a 10-meter-high wall. The main entrance is through the Meridian Gate, which leads to the first courtyard, the largest in the complex. The second courtyard contains the Hall of Supreme Harmony, the largest and most important building in the Forbidden City. It was used for important ceremonies and state occasions, such as the emperor's birthday and the New Year's Day. The third courtyard contains the Hall of Central Harmony, which was used by the emperor to prepare for ceremonies and to rest. The fourth courtyard contains the Hall of Preserving Harmony, which was used for imperial examinations and banquets. The fifth courtyard contains the Imperial Garden, a private garden for the emperor and his family. The Forbidden City is known for its exquisite architecture and decoration. The buildings are decorated with intricate carvings, colorful paintings, and beautiful tiles. The roofs are adorned with dragon and phoenix motifs, which symbolize the emperor and empress, respectively. The Forbidden City was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1987. It is one of the most visited tourist attractions in China, with millions of visitors every year. The palace complex has also been used as a filming location for many movies, including "The Last Emperor" and "Mulan." In recent years, the Chinese government has undertaken a major restoration project to preserve and protect the Forbidden City. The project includes repairing and restoring the buildings, improving the drainage system, and upgrading the lighting and security systems. Overall, the Forbidden City is a magnificent example of Chinese imperial architecture and culture. It is a must-see destination for anyone visiting Beijing or interested in Chinese history and culture.

Sistine Chapel.passage: The Sistine Chapel is a chapel in the Apostolic Palace, the official residence of the Pope, in Vatican City. Originally known as the Cappella Magna, the chapel takes its name from Pope Sixtus IV, who restored it between 1477 and 1480. Since that time, the chapel has served as a site for important religious and ceremonial events, including the election of new popes. The Sistine Chapel is perhaps best known for its ceiling, which was painted by Michelangelo between 1508 and 1512. The ceiling depicts scenes from the Book of Genesis, including the creation of Adam and Eve and the story of Noah's Ark. The frescoes are considered some of the greatest works of art in Western civilization, and they have been admired and studied by artists and scholars for centuries. In addition to Michelangelo's ceiling, the Sistine Chapel is also home to a number of other important works of art. The walls of the chapel are decorated with frescoes by a number of Renaissance artists, including Sandro Botticelli, Pietro Perugino, and Domenico Ghirlandaio. These frescoes depict scenes from the lives of Moses and Christ, and they are considered some of the finest examples of Renaissance art in existence. The Sistine Chapel is also home to a number of important sculptures, including a statue of Saint Peter by Arnolfo di Cambio and a statue of Saint Paul by Giuseppe Obici. The chapel also contains a number of important relics, including the tombs of several popes and the famous Pieta sculpture by Michelangelo. Today, the Sistine Chapel is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Rome, drawing millions of visitors each year. The chapel is open to the public for most of the year, although it is closed during important religious ceremonies and events. Despite the crowds, visitors to the Sistine Chapel are often struck by the beauty and majesty of the space, and many leave feeling deeply moved by the art and history that surrounds them.

Golden Gate Bridge.passage: The Golden Gate Bridge is a suspension bridge spanning the Golden Gate, the one-mile-wide (1.6 km) strait connecting San Francisco Bay and the Pacific Ocean. The structure links the American city of San Francisco, California – the northern tip of the San Francisco Peninsula – to Marin County, carrying both U.S. Route 101 and California State Route 1 across the strait. The bridge is one of the most internationally recognized symbols of San Francisco, California, and the United States. It has been declared one of the Wonders of the Modern World by the American Society of Civil Engineers. The idea of a bridge spanning the Golden Gate strait was first proposed in the early 19th century. However, it was not until the early 20th century that plans for such a bridge were seriously considered. The project was initially opposed by many, including the military, who feared that the bridge would interfere with ship traffic. However, after years of debate and planning, construction of the bridge began in 1933. The bridge was designed by Joseph Strauss, an engineer who had long dreamed of building a bridge across the Golden Gate. Strauss's design called for a suspension bridge with two main towers, each standing 746 feet (227 meters) tall. The bridge would be supported by two main cables, each made up of thousands of individual wires. The cables would be anchored to massive concrete blocks on either side of the strait. Construction of the bridge was a massive undertaking, involving thousands of workers and costing millions of dollars. The project faced numerous challenges, including strong winds, rough seas, and difficult terrain. However, despite these obstacles, the bridge was completed in just over four years, opening to traffic on May 27, 1937. Since its completion, the Golden Gate Bridge has become one of the most iconic landmarks in the United States. It has been featured in countless films, television shows, and photographs, and has become a symbol of San Francisco and the American West. The bridge is also a major tourist attraction, drawing millions of visitors each year. Despite its fame and popularity, the Golden Gate Bridge has also been the site of numerous suicides. In response, the bridge has implemented a number of suicide prevention measures, including a hotline and a physical barrier designed to deter jumpers. Today, the Golden Gate Bridge remains one of the most impressive engineering feats of the 20th century. It is a testament to human ingenuity and perseverance, and a symbol of the enduring spirit of San Francisco and the United States.

Sagrada Familia.passage: The Basílica de la Sagrada Família, also known as the Sagrada Família, is a large unfinished Roman Catholic minor basilica in the Eixample district of Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. Designed by Catalan architect Antoni Gaudí (1852–1926), his work on the building is part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site. On 7 November 2010, Pope Benedict XVI consecrated the church and proclaimed it a minor basilica. Although incomplete, the church is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and in November 2010 was consecrated and proclaimed a minor basilica by Pope Benedict XVI. It is one of the most visited tourist attractions in Barcelona, with millions of visitors annually. The construction of Sagrada Família began in 1882, and Gaudí became involved in 1883, taking over the project and transforming it with his architectural and engineering style, combining Gothic and curvilinear Art Nouveau forms. Gaudí devoted his last years to the project, and at the time of his death at age 73 in 1926, less than a quarter of the project was complete. Sagrada Família's construction progressed slowly, as it relied on private donations and was interrupted by the Spanish Civil War, only resuming intermittent progress in the 1950s. Construction passed the midpoint in 2010 with some of the project's greatest challenges remaining, including the construction of ten more spires, each symbolizing an important Biblical figure in the New Testament. The basilica has a long history of dividing the citizens of Barcelona: over the initial possibility it might compete with Barcelona's cathedral, over Gaudí's design itself, over the possibility that work after Gaudí's death disregarded his design, and the 2007 proposal to build an underground tunnel of Spain's high-speed train directly beneath the basilica's main façade, which could have caused structural damage to the building. Describing Sagrada Família, art critic Rainer Zerbst said "it is probably impossible to find a church building anything like it in the entire history of art", and Paul Goldberger describes it as "the most extraordinary personal interpretation of Gothic architecture since the Middle Ages".

Empire State Building.passage: The Empire State Building is a skyscraper located in Midtown Manhattan, New York City. It was designed by Shreve, Lamb & Harmon and completed in 1931. At 1,454 feet (443.2 meters) tall, it was the tallest building in the world until the completion of the World Trade Center's North Tower in 1970. It is currently the fifth-tallest freestanding structure in the Americas. The building's construction was part of a competition between Walter Chrysler of the Chrysler Corporation and John Jakob Raskob of General Motors to see who could build the tallest building. The Empire State Building was completed in just over a year, with construction workers completing an average of four and a half floors per week. The building has 102 floors and is made of steel and concrete. It has a total floor area of 2,768,591 square feet (257,211 square meters). The building's exterior is made of Indiana limestone and granite, and it is decorated with Art Deco motifs. The Empire State Building has been a popular tourist attraction since it opened to the public in 1931. Visitors can take an elevator to the 86th floor observation deck, which offers panoramic views of New York City. There is also a smaller observation deck on the 102nd floor. The building has been featured in numerous films and television shows, including King Kong, Sleepless in Seattle, and Friends. It has also been the site of several notable events, including a plane crash in 1945 and a suicide attempt by a woman who jumped from the 86th floor in 1979. In recent years, the Empire State Building has undergone a series of renovations to improve its energy efficiency and reduce its carbon footprint. These renovations include the installation of new windows, the replacement of the building's heating and cooling systems, and the addition of a green roof. Overall, the Empire State Building remains an iconic symbol of New York City and a testament to the ingenuity and determination of its builders.

The Alhambra..passage: The Alhambra is a palace and fortress complex located in Granada, Andalusia, Spain. It was originally constructed as a small fortress in 889 AD on the remains of Roman fortifications, and was later converted into a royal palace in the mid-13th century by the Nasrid dynasty. The complex is known for its stunning Islamic architecture, intricate tilework, and beautiful gardens. The Alhambra is divided into three main sections: the Alcazaba, the Nasrid Palaces, and the Generalife. The Alcazaba is the oldest part of the complex and served as a military fortress. It features a series of towers and walls that offer stunning views of the surrounding area. The Nasrid Palaces are the most famous part of the Alhambra and are known for their intricate tilework and ornate decoration. The Generalife is a series of gardens and orchards that were used as a summer palace by the Nasrid rulers. The Alhambra has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1984 and is one of the most visited tourist attractions in Spain. It has inspired countless artists and writers over the centuries, including Washington Irving, who wrote his famous Tales of the Alhambra while living in the complex in the 19th century. Despite its popularity, the Alhambra has faced numerous challenges over the years. It was damaged during the Napoleonic Wars and suffered from neglect in the 19th and early 20th centuries. However, extensive restoration work has been carried out in recent years to preserve the complex for future generations. Today, visitors to the Alhambra can explore the various sections of the complex and marvel at its stunning architecture and decoration. The complex is open to the public year-round, although tickets must be purchased in advance due to its popularity.

The Great Wall of China.passage: The Great Wall of China is a series of fortifications made of stone, brick, tamped earth, wood, and other materials, generally built along an east-to-west line across the historical northern borders of China to protect the Chinese states and empires against the raids and invasions of the various nomadic groups of the Eurasian Steppe. Several walls were being built from as early as the 7th century BC by ancient Chinese states; selective stretches were later joined together by Qin Shi Huang (220–206 BC), the first emperor of China. Little of the Qin wall remains. Later on, many successive dynasties have built and maintained multiple stretches of border walls. The most well-known sections of the wall were built by the Ming dynasty (1368–1644). Apart from defense, other purposes of the Great Wall have included border controls, allowing the imposition of duties on goods transported along the Silk Road, regulation or encouragement of trade and the control of immigration and emigration. Furthermore, the defensive characteristics of the Great Wall were enhanced by the construction of watchtowers, troop barracks, garrison stations, signaling capabilities through the means of smoke or fire, and the fact that the path of the Great Wall also served as a transportation corridor. The Great Wall stretches from Dandong in the east to Lop Lake in the west, along an arc that roughly delineates the southern edge of Inner Mongolia. A comprehensive archaeological survey, using advanced technologies, has concluded that the Ming walls measure 8,850 km (5,500 mi). This is made up of 6,259 km (3,889 mi) sections of actual wall, 359 km (223 mi) of trenches and 2,232 km (1,387 mi) of natural defensive barriers such as hills and rivers. The Great Wall is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and a popular tourist destination. The wall is generally recognized as one of the most impressive architectural feats in history. The Great Wall of China has become a symbol of Chinese civilization, and its history and cultural significance attract millions of visitors every year.

Las Vegas Strip.passage: The Las Vegas Strip is a stretch of South Las Vegas Boulevard in Clark County, Nevada, known for its concentration of resort hotels and casinos. The Strip is approximately 4.2 miles (6.8 km) in length, located immediately south of the Las Vegas city limits in the unincorporated towns of Paradise and Winchester. However, the Strip is often referred to as being in Las Vegas. Many of the largest hotel, casino, and resort properties in the world are located on the Las Vegas Strip. Fifteen of the world's 25 largest hotels by room count are on the Strip, with a total of over 62,000 rooms. One of the most iconic landmarks on the Strip is the Welcome to Fabulous Las Vegas sign, located at the southern end of the Strip near the airport. The sign was designed by Betty Willis in 1959 and has become a symbol of Las Vegas. The first hotel on the Strip was the El Rancho Vegas, which opened in 1941. The hotel was later destroyed by a fire in 1960. The first high-rise hotel on the Strip was the Riviera, which opened in 1955. The Riviera was demolished in 2016 to make way for a convention center expansion. Other notable hotels on the Strip include the Bellagio, Caesars Palace, the Venetian, the Wynn, and the MGM Grand. The Bellagio is known for its iconic fountain show, which features water jets choreographed to music. Caesars Palace is known for its Roman-themed architecture and its Colosseum theater, which has hosted many famous performers over the years. The Strip is also home to many famous restaurants, nightclubs, and shopping destinations. The Forum Shops at Caesars Palace is one of the most popular shopping destinations on the Strip, featuring high-end retailers such as Gucci, Louis Vuitton, and Versace. The Las Vegas Strip is a major tourist destination, attracting millions of visitors each year. The Strip is also a major contributor to the economy of Las Vegas and the state of Nevada, generating billions of dollars in revenue each year.
