Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi..passage: Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi was a French sculptor who is best known for designing the Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor. Born in Colmar, France in 1834, Bartholdi studied art in Paris and Rome before returning to his hometown to open his own studio. He gained recognition for his public monuments and sculptures, including a statue of General Rapp in Colmar and a monument to Lafayette in New York City. In 1871, Bartholdi began working on the design for the Statue of Liberty, which was intended as a gift from France to the United States to commemorate the centennial of American independence. The statue, which depicts a woman holding a torch and a tablet inscribed with the date of the Declaration of Independence, was completed in 1884 and shipped to the United States the following year. Bartholdi continued to work on public monuments and sculptures throughout his career, including a statue of Marquis de Lafayette in Paris and a monument to Christopher Columbus in Santo Domingo. He died in 1904 at the age of 70, leaving behind a legacy as one of the most celebrated sculptors of his time.

Bedloe's Island..passage: Bedloe's Island is a small island in New York Harbor, located approximately 2.5 miles southwest of Manhattan. The island was originally known as "Love Island" and was used as a quarantine station for ships arriving in New York City. In 1827, the island was purchased by the federal government and was renamed Bedloe's Island in honor of Isaac Bedloe, a Dutch-American merchant who owned the island in the late 17th century. In 1886, Bedloe's Island became the site of the Statue of Liberty, a gift from the people of France to the United States. The statue was designed by French sculptor Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi and was constructed in France before being shipped to the United States in pieces. The statue was reassembled on Bedloe's Island and dedicated on October 28, 1886, in a ceremony attended by President Grover Cleveland and other dignitaries. Today, Bedloe's Island is officially known as Liberty Island and is a popular tourist destination, attracting millions of visitors each year. In addition to the Statue of Liberty, the island is home to a museum and gift shop, as well as several restaurants and other amenities. Gustave Eiffel..passage: Gustave Eiffel (1832-1923) was a French civil engineer and architect who is best known for designing the Eiffel Tower in Paris. He was born in Dijon, France and studied at the École Centrale des Arts et Manufactures in Paris. After graduation, he worked for several years as an engineer before starting his own company in 1866. Eiffel's company specialized in designing and constructing metal structures, including bridges, viaducts, and railway stations. He was known for his innovative use of iron and steel, which allowed him to create structures that were both strong and lightweight. In 1884, Eiffel was approached by the French government to design a monument for the 1889 World's Fair in Paris. He proposed a 300-meter-tall tower made of iron, which would be the tallest structure in the world at the time. Despite initial opposition from some members of the public and the artistic community, the tower was eventually built and became an instant icon of Paris. Eiffel continued to work on a variety of projects throughout his career, including the Garabit viaduct in France and the Statue of Liberty in New York. He was also involved in the construction of several bridges and railway stations in South America and Asia. Eiffel was a member of the French Academy of Sciences and received numerous awards and honors for his work. He died in Paris in 1923 at the age of 91. Today, the Eiffel Tower remains one of the most recognizable landmarks in the world and a testament to Eiffel's engineering genius.

New York City..passage: New York City (NYC), often simply called New York, is the most populous city in the United States. With an estimated 2019 population of 8,336,817 distributed over about 302.6 square miles (784 km2), New York City is also the most densely populated major city in the United States. Located at the southern tip of the State of New York, the city is the center of the New York metropolitan area, the largest metropolitan area in the world by urban landmass. With almost 20 million people in its metropolitan statistical area and approximately 23 million in its combined statistical area, it is one of the world's most populous megacities. New York City has been described as the cultural, financial, and media capital of the world, significantly influencing commerce, entertainment, research, technology, education, politics, tourism, art, fashion, and sports. Home to the headquarters of the United Nations, New York is an important center for international diplomacy.

Australia..passage: Australia, officially known as the Commonwealth of Australia, is a sovereign country comprising the mainland of the Australian continent, the island of Tasmania, and numerous smaller islands. It is the world's sixth-largest country by total area. The population of Australia is approximately 26 million people, making it the world's 52nd most populous country. Australia's capital is Canberra, and its largest city is Sydney. Indigenous Australians inhabited the continent for about 65,000 years prior to the first arrival of Dutch explorers in the early 17th century, who named it New Holland. In 1770, James Cook claimed the east coast of Australia for Great Britain, and the British established a penal colony in New South Wales in 1788. The population grew steadily in the following years, and by the 1850s, Australia was experiencing a gold rush, which led to the establishment of several new cities. Australia is a highly developed country with a strong economy and a high standard of living. It is a member of the United Nations, G20, Commonwealth of Nations, ANZUS, Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), World Trade Organization, Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, and the Pacific Islands Forum. Australia is also known for its unique flora and fauna, including kangaroos, koalas, and the Great Barrier Reef. Australia is a constitutional monarchy with a parliamentary system of government. The Queen of Australia, currently Queen Elizabeth II, is also the monarch of 15 other Commonwealth realms. The Australian government is divided into three branches: the executive branch, headed by the Prime Minister; the legislative branch, consisting of the bicameral Parliament; and the judicial branch, headed by the High Court of Australia. Australia is a multicultural society, with a diverse population that includes people of European, Asian, and Indigenous backgrounds. English is the official language, but many other languages are also spoken, reflecting the country's diverse cultural heritage. Australia is also known for its sports culture, with cricket, rugby, and Australian rules football being popular national pastimes.

Arizona..passage: Arizona is a state in the southwestern region of the United States. It is also part of the Western and the Mountain states. It is the sixth largest and the 14th most populous of the 50 states. Its capital and largest city is Phoenix. Arizona shares the Four Corners region with Utah, Colorado, and New Mexico; its other neighboring states are Nevada and California to the west and the Mexican states of Sonora and Baja California to the south and southwest. Arizona is known for its desert climate, exceptionally hot summers, and mild winters, but it also features pine forests and mountain ranges in the northern high country, with much cooler weather than the lower deserts. The state's name appears to originate from an earlier Spanish name, Arizonac, derived from the O'odham name alĭ ṣonak, meaning "small spring", which initially applied only to an area near the silver mining camp of Planchas de Plata, Sonora. To the European settlers, their pronunciation sounded like "Arissona". The area is still known as alĭ ṣonak in the O'odham language. Another possible origin is the Basque phrase haritz ona ("the good oak"), as there were numerous Basque sheepherders in the area.

Colorado River..passage: The Colorado River is a major river in the western United States and Mexico, approximately 1,450 miles long. The river drains an expansive, arid watershed that encompasses parts of seven U.S. and two Mexican states. Starting in the central Rocky Mountains of Colorado, the river flows generally southwest across the Colorado Plateau and through the Grand Canyon before reaching Lake Mead on the Arizona–Nevada border, where it turns south toward the international border. After entering Mexico, the Colorado approaches the Gulf of California and forms a large delta, emptying into the sea as a freshwater estuary. The river and its tributaries are controlled by an extensive system of dams, reservoirs, and aqueducts, which provide water for irrigation, municipal, and industrial uses throughout the southwestern United States.

Theodore Roosevelt..passage: Theodore Roosevelt Jr. (October 27, 1858 – January 6, 1919) was an American statesman, politician, conservationist, naturalist, and writer who served as the 26th president of the United States from 1901 to 1909. He served as the 25th vice president from March to September 1901 and as the 33rd governor of New York from 1899 to 1900. As a leader of the Republican Party during this time, he became a driving force for the Progressive Era in the United States in the early 20th century. His face is depicted on Mount Rushmore alongside George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and Abraham Lincoln.

Cusco Region..passage: The Cusco Region is a region in southeastern Peru. Its capital is Cusco, the historic capital of the Inca Empire. The region is home to many archaeological sites, including Machu Picchu, the Sacred Valley of the Incas, and the Inca Trail. The region's economy is based on agriculture, mining, and tourism. The region is also known for its traditional textiles and handicrafts. The Cusco Region is divided into thirteen provinces, which are further divided into districts. The region has a population of approximately 1.3 million people.

Vilcabamba..passage: Vilcabamba (Spanish pronunciation: [bilkaˈβamba]) is a village in the southern region of Ecuador, in the Loja province, about 45 km (28 mi) south of the city of Loja. The etymology of the name "Vilcabamba" apparently derives from the Quichua "huilco pamba." Huilco denotes the sacred trees, Anadenanthera colubrina, that inhabit the region; pamba (cognate with pampa) is a word meaning "a plain". The area has been referred to as the "Playground of the Inca" which refers to its historic use as a retreat for Incan royalty. The valley is overlooked by a mountain called Mandango, the Sleeping Inca, whose presence is said to protect the area from earthquakes and other natural disasters. The village is located on a high altitude plateau at 1,500 m (4,921 ft) above sea level, surrounded by the mountains of the Andes. The climate is mild and spring-like year-round, with temperatures ranging from 18 to 28 °C (64 to 82 °F). The area is known for its natural beauty, with lush vegetation, waterfalls, and hiking trails. Vilcabamba has become a popular destination for tourists seeking a peaceful and healthy lifestyle, with many expatriates from North America and Europe settling in the area. The village has a small but thriving economy based on agriculture, tourism, and handicrafts.

Pachacuti..passage: Pachacuti Inca Yupanqui (Quechua: Pachakutiq Inka Yupanki, "he who overturns space and time"; c. 1438 – 1471) was the ninth Sapa Inca (1438–1471/1472) of the Kingdom of Cusco, which he transformed into the Inca Empire (Tawantinsuyu). Most archaeologists now believe that the famous Inca site of Machu Picchu was built as an estate for Pachacuti. He was also responsible for a significant expansion of the Inca Empire, conquering the Kingdom of Chimor, the Chancay, and the Cañari. Pachacuti's reforms included an improved road system, irrigation systems, and the creation of a centralized government. He also ordered the construction of several palaces and temples, including the Temple of the Sun (Coricancha) in Cusco. Pachacuti's legacy is still felt in modern-day Peru, where he is revered as a national hero and cultural icon.

Hiram Bingham..passage: Hiram Bingham III (November 19, 1875 – June 6, 1956) was an American academic, explorer, and politician who is best known for his discovery of the ancient Incan city of Machu Picchu in 1911. Bingham was born in Honolulu, Hawaii, and grew up in Connecticut. He attended Yale University, where he earned a degree in Latin American history and later a PhD in anthropology. Bingham's interest in South America began during his travels to Peru in 1906, where he studied the Inca civilization. In 1911, Bingham led an expedition to the Andes Mountains in search of the lost city of Vilcabamba, the last refuge of the Inca Empire. Instead, he stumbled upon Machu Picchu, which had been abandoned for centuries. Bingham's discovery of Machu Picchu brought international attention to the site and helped to establish the importance of Inca civilization. Bingham later served as a United States Senator from Connecticut and as Governor of Connecticut. He continued to explore and write about South America throughout his life, and his legacy as an explorer and scholar remains significant.

The Temple of the Sun..passage: The Temple of the Sun, also known as the Inti Watana, is an ancient Incan temple located in Machu Picchu, Peru. It is believed to have been built during the 15th century and was dedicated to the Incan sun god, Inti. The temple is situated on a hilltop and offers stunning views of the surrounding mountains and valleys. The structure is made of large, precisely cut stones that fit together without the use of mortar. The temple's most notable feature is the Inti Watana stone, which is a carved granite rock that served as a solar clock and calendar for the Incas. The stone is positioned in such a way that it casts a shadow that moves throughout the day, indicating the time of day and the changing seasons. The temple was likely used for religious ceremonies and astronomical observations, and it is considered to be one of the most important Incan sites in Peru. Today, the Temple of the Sun is a popular tourist destination and is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Rajasthan..passage: Rajasthan is a state in northern India, bordering Pakistan. Its palaces and forts are reminders of the many kingdoms that historically vied for the region. In its capital, Jaipur (the "Pink City"), are the 18th-century City Palace and Hawa Mahal, a former cloister for royal women, fronted by a 5-story pink-sandstone screen. Amer Fort, atop a nearby hill, was built by a Rajput prince in the early 1600s. The state is also known for its desert landscapes, including the Thar Desert, which extends into Pakistan. The desert is home to several national parks and wildlife sanctuaries, including the Sariska Tiger Reserve and Ranthambore National Park, which is known for its tigers and other wildlife. Rajasthan is also famous for its textiles, including block-printed fabrics and embroidered garments, as well as its jewelry, pottery, and other handicrafts. The state's cuisine is known for its spicy curries and sweets, such as the famous Rajasthani dessert, ghevar.

Shah Jahan..passage: Shah Jahan was the fifth Mughal emperor, who ruled from 1628 to 1658. He is widely considered to be one of the greatest Mughal emperors, known for his architectural achievements, including the Taj Mahal, which he built in memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal. Shah Jahan was born in 1592 in Lahore, in present-day Pakistan, and was the third son of Emperor Jahangir. He was named Prince Khurram, but later changed his name to Shah Jahan, which means "King of the World." Shah Jahan was a skilled military commander and expanded the Mughal Empire to its greatest extent. However, he is perhaps best known for his patronage of the arts and architecture, which reached its peak during his reign. In addition to the Taj Mahal, Shah Jahan commissioned the construction of many other impressive buildings, including the Red Fort in Delhi and the Jama Masjid in Agra. Despite his many achievements, Shah Jahan's reign was marked by political turmoil and family strife. He was deposed by his own son Aurangzeb in 1658 and spent the rest of his life under house arrest in the Agra Fort, where he died in 1666.

Wyoming..passage: Wyoming is a state in the mountain region of the western United States. Wyoming is bordered on the north by Montana, on the east by South Dakota and Nebraska, on the south by Colorado, on the southwest by Utah, and on the west by Idaho. The state population was estimated at 578,759 in 2019. The state capital and the most populous city is Cheyenne, which had an estimated population of 64,235 in 2019. The western two-thirds of the state is covered mostly by the mountain ranges and rangelands of the Rocky Mountains, while the eastern third of the state is high elevation prairie called the High Plains. Almost half of the land in Wyoming is owned by the U.S. government, leading Wyoming to rank sixth by area and fifth by proportion of a state's land owned by the federal government. Federal lands include two national parks—Grand Teton and Yellowstone—two national recreation areas, two national monuments, several national forests, historic sites, fish hatcheries, and wildlife refuges.

Montana..passage: Montana is a state located in the northwestern region of the United States. It is bordered by North Dakota to the east, South Dakota and Wyoming to the south, Idaho to the west, and the Canadian provinces of British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan to the north. The state's capital is Helena, and its largest city is Billings. Montana is the fourth-largest state by area, covering 147,040 square miles (380,800 km2), and the eighth-least populous state, with a population of approximately 1.07 million people. The western half of Montana contains numerous mountain ranges, while the eastern half is characterized by prairie terrain and badlands. The economy is primarily based on agriculture, including ranching and cereal grain farming. Other significant economic resources include oil, gas, coal, hard rock mining, and lumber. Tourism is also important, with millions of visitors annually drawn to Glacier National Park, the Battle of Little Bighorn site, and three of the five entrances to Yellowstone National Park.

Yellowstone..passage: Yellowstone National Park is a national park located primarily in the U.S. state of Wyoming, although it also extends into Montana and Idaho. It was established by the U.S. Congress and signed into law by President Ulysses S. Grant on March 1, 1872. Yellowstone was the first national park in the U.S. and is widely considered to be the first national park in the world. The park is known for its geothermal features, including the famous Old Faithful geyser, as well as its diverse wildlife, such as grizzly bears, wolves, and herds of bison and elk. Yellowstone is also home to the Yellowstone Caldera, which is one of the largest active volcanic systems in the world. The park covers an area of 2.2 million acres and attracts millions of visitors each year.

Yellowstone Caldera..passage: The Yellowstone Caldera is a volcanic caldera and supervolcano in Yellowstone National Park in the Western United States, sometimes referred to as the Yellowstone Supervolcano. The caldera and most of the park are located in the northwest corner of Wyoming. The major features of the caldera measure about 34 by 45 miles (55 by 72 km). The caldera formed during the last of three supereruptions over the past 2.1 million years: the Huckleberry Ridge eruption 2.1 million years ago (which created the Island Park Caldera and the Huckleberry Ridge Tuff), the Mesa Falls eruption 1.3 million years ago (which created the Henry's Fork Caldera and the Mesa Falls Tuff) and the Lava Creek eruption approximately 630,000 years ago (which created the Yellowstone Caldera and the Lava Creek Tuff).

Yellowstone River..passage: The Yellowstone River is a tributary of the Missouri River, approximately 692 miles (1,114 km) long, in the western United States. Considered the principal tributary of the upper Missouri, the river and its tributaries drain a wide area stretching from the Rocky Mountains in the vicinity of Yellowstone National Park across the mountains and high plains of southern Montana and northern Wyoming. The Yellowstone River watershed is a river basin covering 70,000 square miles (181,300 km²), extending from the Rocky Mountains in Montana to the western edge of North Dakota. The Yellowstone River is a popular destination for fly fishing, and is widely considered to be one of the premier trout fishing rivers in the United States. The river is also a popular destination for rafting and kayaking, with numerous rapids and scenic stretches along its length. The Yellowstone River is an important source of water for irrigation and other uses, and is also a major source of hydroelectric power in the region. The river is also home to a variety of wildlife, including grizzly bears, wolves, elk, and bison, and is an important part of the ecosystem of Yellowstone National Park.

The Parthenon..passage: The Parthenon is a temple located on the Acropolis hill in Athens, Greece. It was built in the 5th century BCE as a dedication to the goddess Athena, who was considered the patron deity of Athens. The temple was designed by the architects Ictinus and Callicrates, and the sculptor Phidias was responsible for the intricate carvings and sculptures that adorned the building. The Parthenon is considered one of the greatest examples of classical Greek architecture, and it has had a significant impact on the development of Western architecture. The temple is constructed entirely of marble and features a series of columns that support the roof. The building is adorned with intricate carvings and sculptures, including the famous frieze that depicts the Panathenaic procession. Over the centuries, the Parthenon has undergone significant changes and damage. It was converted into a Christian church in the 6th century CE, and later served as a mosque during the Ottoman Empire. In the 17th century, the building was severely damaged during a war between the Venetians and the Ottomans, and many of the sculptures were removed and taken to other parts of Europe. Today, the Parthenon is a popular tourist attraction and a symbol of ancient Greek civilization. Despite the damage it has suffered over the centuries, the building remains an impressive example of classical architecture and a testament to the enduring legacy of the ancient Greeks.

qae_pairs.context: The Parthenon is a temple located on the Acropolis hill in Athens, Greece. It was built in the 5th century BCE as a dedication to the goddess Athena, who was considered the patron deity of Athens.

Acropolis hill..passage: The Acropolis of Athens is an ancient citadel located on a rocky outcrop above the city of Athens and contains the remains of several ancient buildings of great architectural and historic significance, the most famous being the Parthenon. The word acropolis is from the Greek words ἄκρον (akron, "highest point, extremity") and πόλις (polis, "city"). Although the term acropolis is generic and there are many other acropoleis in Greece, the significance of the Acropolis of Athens is such that it is commonly known as "The Acropolis" without qualification. During ancient times it was known also more properly as Cecropia, after the legendary serpent-man, Cecrops, the first Athenian king. While there is evidence that the hill was inhabited as far back as the fourth millennium BC, it was Pericles (c. 495–429 BC) in the fifth century BC who coordinated the construction of the site's most important buildings including the Parthenon, the Propylaia, the Erechtheion and the Temple of Athena Nike. The Parthenon and the other buildings were seriously damaged during the 1687 siege by the Venetians during the Morean War when gunpowder being stored in the Parthenon was hit by a cannonball and exploded. The Acropolis was formally proclaimed as the preeminent monument on the European Cultural Heritage list of monuments on 26 March 2007.

The Temple of Athena Nike..passage: The Temple of Athena Nike is a temple located on the Acropolis of Athens in Greece. It was built in the 5th century BC and is dedicated to the goddess Athena Nike, who was the goddess of victory. The temple is one of the earliest examples of the Ionic order of architecture and is considered to be one of the most important buildings of the Classical period. The temple was designed by the architect Kallikrates and was built to commemorate the Athenian victory over the Persians in the Battle of Marathon. The temple is small in size, measuring only 27 feet by 18 feet, but it is richly decorated with intricate carvings and sculptures. The temple was originally built with four Ionic columns at the front and back, and six columns on each side. The columns are decorated with intricate carvings of acanthus leaves and other decorative motifs. The temple also features a frieze depicting scenes from the Battle of Marathon. The temple has undergone several restorations over the years, including a major restoration in the 19th century. Today, the temple is a popular tourist attraction and is considered to be one of the most important ancient Greek temples in the world.

Nikolaos Balanos..passage: Nikolaos Balanos (1869–1946) was a Greek architect and archaeologist who played a significant role in the preservation and restoration of ancient Greek monuments. Born in Athens, Balanos studied architecture at the National Technical University of Athens and later at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris. He began his career as an architect, designing buildings in Athens and other parts of Greece. In 1896, Balanos was appointed as an architect for the Greek Archaeological Service, and he soon became involved in the restoration of ancient Greek monuments. He worked on a number of important projects, including the restoration of the Temple of Olympian Zeus in Athens and the reconstruction of the Stoa of Attalos in the Ancient Agora of Athens. Balanos was also involved in archaeological excavations, and he participated in the excavation of the ancient city of Delphi. He was appointed as the director of the Delphi Archaeological Museum in 1910, and he played a key role in the development of the museum's collections and exhibitions. Throughout his career, Balanos was committed to the preservation of ancient Greek monuments and the promotion of Greek culture. He was a member of the Archaeological Society of Athens and the Academy of Athens, and he received numerous awards and honors for his work. Today, his legacy lives on in the many monuments and buildings he helped to preserve and restore, and in the ongoing efforts to protect and promote Greece's rich cultural heritage.

Wales..passage: Wales is a country that is part of the United Kingdom and the island of Great Britain. It is bordered by England to the east, the Irish Sea to the north and west, and the Bristol Channel to the south. It has a population of around 3 million and a total area of 20,779 km². The capital and largest city is Cardiff, and other major cities include Swansea, Newport, and Wrexham. Wales has a rich history and culture, with evidence of human habitation dating back to the Paleolithic era. It was conquered by the Romans in the 1st century AD and later became part of the Kingdom of England in the 16th century. Despite this, Wales has maintained a distinct identity and language, with Welsh being spoken by around 20% of the population. The landscape of Wales is diverse, with rugged mountains, rolling hills, and beautiful coastline. It is home to three national parks, including Snowdonia, which contains the highest mountain in Wales, and the Brecon Beacons, which offer stunning views and outdoor activities such as hiking and cycling. Wales is also known for its rich cultural heritage, including traditional music, literature, and art. It is home to many historic sites, such as the castles of Caernarfon and Conwy, and the ancient standing stones of Stonehenge. Today, Wales is a modern and vibrant country, with a thriving economy and a strong sense of community. It is a popular destination for tourists, who come to explore its natural beauty, cultural heritage, and friendly people.

River Thames..passage: The River Thames is a river that flows through southern England, including London. At 215 miles (346 km), it is the longest river entirely in England and the second-longest in the United Kingdom, after the River Severn. The river has played a significant role in the history of England, and its importance has been recognized in literature, art, and music. The Thames is a major economic resource, providing water for agriculture, industry, and drinking, as well as serving as a transportation route. It is also a popular tourist destination, with many attractions along its banks, including historic buildings, parks, and museums. The river is home to a variety of wildlife, including fish, birds, and mammals, and is an important habitat for many species. Despite its importance, the Thames has faced many challenges, including pollution, flooding, and erosion. Efforts are underway to address these issues and ensure the river remains a vital resource for generations to come.

City of London Corporation..passage: The City of London Corporation, officially and legally the Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, is the municipal governing body of the City of London, the historic centre of London and the location of much of the United Kingdom's financial sector. In 2006 the name was changed from Corporation of London to avoid confusion with the wider London local government, the Greater London Authority. The corporation's structure includes the Lord Mayor, the Court of Aldermen, the Court of Common Council, and the Freemen and Livery of the City. The corporation has various functions, including responsibility for the City of London's police force, the City of London Police, for administration of the Barbican Centre and the Guildhall School of Music and Drama, and for support of the City of London's economic and cultural advancement, including through the City of London Corporation's charity, the City Bridge Trust. It is also responsible for maintaining the City's historic and architectural heritage, and for providing local government services to the City's residents and workers.

National Rail..passage: National Rail is the brand name used by the Rail Delivery Group (RDG) of the United Kingdom for the passenger railway services provided by the private train operating companies (TOCs) in England, Wales, and Scotland. The National Rail network comprises a combination of the former British Rail lines that have been privatised, and new passenger-carrying infrastructure that has been built since privatisation. The majority of the network is managed by Network Rail, a publicly owned company that is responsible for the infrastructure, such as tracks, signalling, bridges, tunnels, level crossings, and stations. National Rail services are operated under a franchise system, where private companies bid for the right to operate services on specific routes for a set period of time. The RDG is responsible for setting fares and ticketing, coordinating timetables, and promoting the National Rail brand. National Rail services carry over 1.7 billion passengers annually, making it one of the busiest railway networks in the world.

Johann Ludwig Burckhardt..passage: Johann Ludwig Burckhardt (1784-1817) was a Swiss explorer and orientalist who is best known for his travels in the Middle East and his rediscovery of the ancient city of Petra in modern-day Jordan. Born in Lausanne, Switzerland, Burckhardt was educated in Germany and England before embarking on a career as a traveler and scholar. He traveled extensively throughout the Middle East, often disguised as a Muslim, and became fluent in Arabic and several other languages. In 1812, he arrived in Cairo, where he spent several years studying Arabic and Islamic culture. In 1817, he set out on a journey to explore the region around the Dead Sea, and it was during this trip that he discovered Petra, which had been lost to the Western world for centuries. Burckhardt's writings and drawings of Petra helped to popularize the site and sparked renewed interest in the study of ancient Near Eastern cultures. He died later that year of dysentery, but his legacy as a pioneering explorer and scholar of the Middle East lives on.

John William Burgon..passage: John William Burgon (1813-1888) was an English Anglican divine, theologian, and scholar. He was born in Smyrna, Turkey, where his father was a merchant. He was a prolific writer and his works include commentaries on the Bible, sermons, and theological treatises. Burgon was also a skilled textual critic and was involved in the editing of the Greek New Testament. He was a member of the committee that produced the Revised Version of the New Testament in 1881. Burgon was a controversial figure in his time, and his views on theology and textual criticism were often criticized by his contemporaries. However, he was highly respected for his scholarship and his contributions to the study of the Bible. Burgon died in 1888 and is buried in the churchyard of St. Mary's Church in Oxford.

UNESCO..passage: UNESCO (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization) is a specialized agency of the United Nations (UN) based in Paris, France. Roman Empire..passage: The Roman Empire was the post-Republican period of ancient Rome, characterized by government headed by emperors and large territorial holdings around the Mediterranean Sea in Europe, Africa and Asia. The city of Rome was the largest city in the world c. 100 BC – c. AD 400, with Constantinople (New Rome) becoming the largest around AD 500, and the Empire's populace grew to an estimated 50 to 90 million inhabitants (roughly 20% of the world's population at the time) during its 500-year history. The 500-year-old republic which preceded it was severely destabilized in a series of civil wars and political conflict, during which Julius Caesar was appointed as perpetual dictator and then assassinated in 44 BC. Civil wars and executions continued, culminating in the victory of Octavian, Caesar's adopted son, over Mark Antony and Cleopatra at the Battle of Actium in 31 BC. The following year, Octavian conquered Ptolemaic Egypt, ending the Hellenistic period that had begun with the conquests of Alexander the Great of Macedon in the 4th century BC. Octavian's power was then unassailable and in 27 BC the Roman Senate formally granted him overarching power and the new title Augustus, effectively marking the end of the Roman Republic. The imperial successor to the Republic endured for some 500 years.

Cambodia..passage: Cambodia, officially known as the Kingdom of Cambodia, is a country located in the southern portion of the Indochina peninsula in Southeast Asia. It is bordered by Thailand to the northwest, Laos to the northeast, Vietnam to the east, and the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest. The country has a population of over 15 million people, with the majority of the population being of Khmer ethnicity. The official language is Khmer, and the country's capital and largest city is Phnom Penh. Cambodia has a rich history, with evidence of human habitation dating back to the Paleolithic era. The Khmer Empire, which ruled over much of Southeast Asia from the 9th to the 15th century, left behind impressive architectural and artistic achievements, including the famous Angkor Wat temple complex. However, the country has also experienced periods of conflict and instability, including the brutal rule of the Khmer Rouge regime in the 1970s, which resulted in the deaths of an estimated 1.7 million people. Today, Cambodia is a developing country with a growing economy, driven in part by tourism and the garment industry. However, the country still faces challenges such as poverty, corruption, and political instability. The government has made efforts to address these issues, including implementing economic reforms and investing in infrastructure. Cambodia is also known for its natural beauty, including its beaches, forests, and wildlife, as well as its rich cultural heritage.

David Livingstone..passage: David Livingstone was a Scottish physician, Congregationalist, and pioneer Christian missionary with the London Missionary Society, an explorer in Africa, and one of the most popular British heroes of the late 19th-century Victorian era. He had a mythical status that operated on a number of interconnected levels: Protestant missionary martyr, working-class "rags-to-riches" inspirational story, scientific investigator and explorer, imperial reformer, anti-slavery crusader, and advocate of commercial and colonial expansion. His fame as an explorer helped drive forward the obsession with discovering the sources of the Nile that formed the culmination of the classic period of European geographical discovery and colonial penetration of the African continent. At the same time, his missionary travels, "disappearance" and death in Africa, and subsequent glorification as posthumous national hero in 1874 led to the founding of several major central African Christian missionary initiatives carried forward in the era of the European "Scramble for Africa".

Queen Victoria..passage: Queen Victoria was the longest-reigning monarch in British history, ruling from 1837 until her death in 1901. She ascended to the throne at the age of 18, following the death of her uncle, King William IV. She was known for her strict moral code and conservative values, as well as her devotion to her husband, Prince Albert, who died in 1861. She was also a patron of the arts and sciences, and her reign saw the development of many important cultural institutions, including the Victoria and Albert Museum and the Royal Albert Hall. Despite her long reign and significant accomplishments, Victoria was also known for her reclusive nature and her tendency to withdraw from public life in her later years.

Colonial era..passage: The Colonial era is a period of history that spans from the 15th century to the mid-20th century, during which European powers established colonies in various parts of the world. The era began with the Portuguese and Spanish exploration of the Americas, Africa, and Asia, and continued with the colonization efforts of other European powers such as the Dutch, French, and British. The primary motivation for colonialism was economic gain, as European powers sought to exploit the resources and labor of the lands they colonized. This led to the establishment of plantation economies, the slave trade, and the extraction of natural resources such as gold, silver, and rubber. The colonial era also had significant cultural and social impacts, as European powers imposed their language, religion, and customs on the indigenous populations of the lands they colonized. The legacy of colonialism is still felt today, as many former colonies continue to struggle with the effects of exploitation, inequality, and cultural erasure.

Antarctica..passage: Antarctica is the southernmost continent and the fifth largest continent in the world. It is located almost entirely within the Antarctic Circle and is surrounded by the Southern Ocean. The continent is divided into two regions: East Antarctica, which is largely composed of a high ice plateau, and West Antarctica, which is dominated by the Antarctic Peninsula and the ice shelves that surround it. Antarctica is the coldest, driest, and windiest continent on Earth, with temperatures reaching as low as -128.6°F (-89.2°C) and winds reaching speeds of up to 200 mph (320 km/h). Despite its harsh conditions, Antarctica is home to a diverse range of wildlife, including penguins, seals, whales, and various species of birds. The continent is also a hub for scientific research, with numerous research stations operated by various countries. The Antarctic Treaty, signed in 1959, designates Antarctica as a scientific preserve and prohibits military activity on the continent.

Earth..passage: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only astronomical object known to harbor life. According to radiometric dating and other sources of evidence, Earth formed over 4.5 billion years ago. Earth's gravity interacts with other objects in space, especially the Sun and the Moon, which is Earth's only natural satellite. Earth orbits around the Sun in 365.256 solar days, a period known as an Earth year. During this time, Earth rotates about its axis about 366.256 times. Earth's axis of rotation is tilted with respect to its orbital plane, producing seasons on Earth. The gravitational interaction between Earth and the Moon causes ocean tides, stabilizes Earth's orientation on its axis, and gradually slows its rotation. Earth's atmosphere consists mostly of nitrogen and oxygen, with small amounts of water vapor, carbon dioxide, and other gases. The atmospheric pressure varies at different layers and is about 1 atm at sea level. Earth's biosphere has significantly altered its atmosphere, oceans, and other abiotic factors, enabling the proliferation of aerobic organisms as well as the formation of the ozone layer which, together with Earth's magnetic field, blocks harmful solar radiation, permitting life on land. The physical properties of the Earth, as well as its geological history and orbit, have allowed life to persist.

Sahara..passage: The Sahara is a desert located on the African continent. It is the largest hot desert in the world, covering an area of approximately 3.6 million square miles. The Sahara has a rich cultural history, with evidence of human habitation dating back thousands of years. Today, the Sahara is an important region for trade, tourism, and scientific research. However, the desert is also facing significant environmental challenges, including desertification and climate change.

Mexico..passage: Mexico, officially the United Mexican States, is a country in the southern portion of North America. It is bordered to the north by the United States; to the south and west by the Pacific Ocean; to the southeast by Guatemala, Belize, and the Caribbean Sea; and to the east by the Gulf of Mexico. Covering almost 2 million square kilometers (over 760,000 square miles), Mexico is the fifth-largest country in the Americas by total area and the 13th largest independent nation in the world. With an estimated population of over 129 million people, it is the tenth most populous country and the most populous Spanish-speaking country in the world. Mexico is a federation comprising 31 states and Mexico City, a special federal entity that is also the capital city and its most populous city. Other metropolises in the country include Guadalajara, Monterrey, Puebla, Toluca, and Tijuana. Pre-Columbian Mexico traces its origins to 8,000 BC and is identified as one of six cradles of civilization; it was home to many advanced Mesoamerican civilizations, most notably the Maya and the Aztecs. In 1521, the Spanish Empire conquered and colonized the territory from its base in Mexico-Tenochtitlan, which was administered as the viceroyalty of New Spain. Three centuries later, Mexico achieved independence from Spain in 1821. The post-independence period was characterized by economic instability, territorial secession, and civil war, including foreign intervention, two empires, and two long domestic dictatorships. The latter led to the Mexican Revolution in 1910, which culminated with the promulgation of the 1917 Constitution and the emergence of the country as a secular, democratic federal republic.

El Castillo..passage: El Castillo, also known as the Temple of Kukulcan, is a Mesoamerican step-pyramid located in the center of the Chichen Itza archaeological site in the Mexican state of Yucatan. The structure was built by the Maya civilization between the 9th and 12th centuries AD and is considered one of the most impressive examples of Mayan architecture. The pyramid stands 98 feet tall and has four sides, each with a staircase leading to the top. The sides of the pyramid are decorated with carvings of serpents, jaguars, and other animals, and the top of the pyramid features a temple dedicated to the Mayan god Kukulcan. The pyramid was used for religious ceremonies and astronomical observations, and its design is believed to be based on the Mayan calendar. Today, El Castillo is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Mexico and is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

The Great Ball Court..passage: The Great Ball Court is a large ancient Mesoamerican ballcourt located in the city of Chichen Itza, Mexico. It is the largest ballcourt in Mesoamerica, measuring 168 meters long and 70 meters wide. The court was built by the Maya civilization between 900 and 1100 AD and was used for playing the Mesoamerican ballgame, a sport that was played throughout the region for over 3,000 years. The ballgame was a ritualistic event that had religious and political significance, and it was often played as a way to resolve conflicts between different groups. The Great Ball Court is known for its unique architecture, which includes two large stone rings that are set high on the walls of the court. The rings are believed to have been used as goals for the ballgame, and players would have had to hit the ball through them in order to score points. The court also features a series of carved stone panels that depict scenes from the ballgame, as well as other important events in Maya history. Today, the Great Ball Court is a popular tourist attraction and is considered one of the most impressive examples of ancient Mesoamerican architecture.

Mesoamerica..passage: Mesoamerica is a region and cultural area in the Americas, extending approximately from central Mexico to Belize, Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, and northern Costa Rica, within which pre-Columbian societies flourished before the Spanish colonization of the Americas in the 15th and 16th centuries. It is one of six areas in the world where ancient civilization arose independently, and the second in the Americas along with Norte Chico (Caral-Supe) in present-day Peru, in the northern coastal region. Mesoamerica was home to many cultural groups, including the Olmec, Maya, Zapotec, Mixtec, Toltec, and Aztec civilizations. The region was also inhabited by numerous indigenous peoples, many of whom developed complex societies and cultures that were interconnected with the larger Mesoamerican world. The Mesoamerican civilizations were known for their advanced knowledge of astronomy, mathematics, and writing systems, as well as their impressive architectural achievements, such as the pyramids and temples of the Maya and Aztec. Today, the region is home to many indigenous communities who continue to preserve and celebrate their rich cultural heritage.

Pacific Ocean..passage: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest of Earth's oceanic divisions. It extends from the Arctic Ocean in the north to the Southern Ocean in the south and is bounded by the continents of Asia and Australia in the west and the Americas in the east. At 165.25 million square kilometers (63.8 million square miles) in area, this largest division of the World Ocean—and, in turn, the hydrosphere—covers about 46% of Earth's water surface and about one-third of its total surface area, making it larger than all of Earth's land area combined. The centers of both the Water Hemisphere and the Western Hemisphere are in the Pacific Ocean. The equator subdivides it into the North Pacific Ocean and the South Pacific Ocean, with two exceptions: the Galápagos and Gilbert Islands, while straddling the equator, are deemed wholly within the South Pacific. Its mean depth is 4,280 meters (14,040 feet).

Darwin..passage: Charles Robert Darwin (12 February 1809 – 19 April 1882) was an English naturalist, geologist and biologist, best known for his contributions to the science of evolution. His proposition that all species of life have descended over time from common ancestors is now widely accepted, and considered a foundational concept in science. In a joint publication with Alfred Russel Wallace, he introduced his scientific theory that this branching pattern of evolution resulted from a process that he called natural selection, in which the struggle for existence has a similar effect to the artificial selection involved in selective breeding. Darwin has been described as one of the most influential figures in human history, and his ideas have had a profound impact on the way we understand the natural world and our place in it.

I.M. Pei..passage: Ieoh Ming Pei (26 April 1917 – 16 May 2019) was a Chinese-American architect. Born in Guangzhou and raised in Hong Kong and Shanghai, Pei drew inspiration at an early age from the gardens at Suzhou. In 1935, he moved to the United States and enrolled in the University of Pennsylvania's architecture school, but quickly transferred to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He was unhappy with the focus at both schools on Beaux-Arts architecture, and spent his free time researching emerging architects, especially Le Corbusier. After graduating, he joined the Harvard Graduate School of Design (GSD) and became a friend of the Bauhaus architects Walter Gropius and Marcel Breuer. In 1948, Pei was recruited by New York City real estate magnate William Zeckendorf, for whom he worked for seven years before establishing his own independent design firm, I. M. Pei & Associates, in 1955. Among the most notable projects he designed during his early career were the Luce Memorial Chapel at Tunghai University in Taiwan (1963), the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colorado (1967), and the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library in Boston (1979). Pei's later work included the Museum of Islamic Art in Doha, Qatar (2008), and the Macao Science Center in Macau (2009). He received numerous awards and honors, including the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 1983, the Japan Art Association's Praemium Imperiale in 1989, and the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1992.

China..passage: China, officially the People's Republic of China, is a country in East Asia. It is the world's most populous country, with a population of around 1.4 billion. Covering approximately 9.6 million square kilometers, it is the world's third or fourth-largest country by area. The country is officially divided into 23 provinces, five autonomous regions, four direct-controlled municipalities (Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, and Chongqing), and the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau. China emerged as one of the world's earliest civilizations, in the fertile basin of the Yellow River in the North China Plain. For millennia, China's political system was based on hereditary monarchies, or dynasties, beginning with the semi-legendary Xia dynasty in 21st century BCE. Since then, China has expanded, fractured, and re-unified numerous times. In the 3rd century BCE, the Qin reunited core China and established the first Chinese empire. The succeeding Han dynasty, which ruled from 206 BCE until 220 CE, saw some of the most advanced technology at that time, including papermaking and the compass, along with agricultural and medical improvements. The invention of gunpowder and movable type in the Tang dynasty (618–907) and Northern Song Dynasty (960–1127) completed the Four Great Inventions. Tang culture spread widely in Asia, as the new Silk Route brought traders to as far as Mesopotamia and the Horn of Africa. The Qing dynasty, which lasted from 1644 until 1912, was the last imperial dynasty of China. In the late 19th century, the Qing dynasty was overthrown following the Boxer Rebellion, which was itself crushed by an international alliance led by the Eight-Nation Alliance. The establishment of the Republic of China in 1912 led to the Chinese Civil War and the division of China into the two political entities of the PRC and the ROC. The PRC is a one-party state governed by the Communist Party of China, with its seat of government in the capital city of Beijing. It exercises jurisdiction over 22 provinces, five autonomous regions, four direct-controlled municipalities (Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, and Chongqing), and the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau. The PRC also claims Taiwan – which is controlled by the ROC – as its 23rd province, a claim controversial due to the complex political status of Taiwan and the unresolved Chinese Civil War.

BC..passage: BC, or Before Christ, is a term used to refer to the period of time before the birth of Jesus Christ. It is a common way of dating historical events and is used in many cultures and religions around the world. The use of BC dates back to the 6th century AD, when a monk named Dionysius Exiguus developed a system for dating events based on the birth of Jesus Christ. This system was later adopted by the Christian church and became the standard way of dating events in Western civilization. Today, BC is still widely used in academic and historical contexts, although some scholars prefer to use the term BCE (Before the Common Era) to avoid religious connotations. Regardless of the terminology used, the concept of BC remains an important tool for understanding the history of human civilization and the development of our modern world.

Ming dynasty..passage: The Ming dynasty was the ruling dynasty of China from 1368 to 1644. It was the last ethnic Han-led dynasty in China, succeeded by the Manchu-led Qing dynasty. The Ming dynasty was founded by Zhu Yuanzhang, a former peasant who rose to power during the collapse of the Mongol-led Yuan dynasty. Under his leadership, the Ming dynasty restored Chinese rule and culture after decades of foreign domination. The dynasty was characterized by its strong central government, extensive public works projects, and cultural achievements, including the construction of the Forbidden City and the voyages of Zheng He. However, the Ming dynasty also faced challenges, including economic instability, corruption, and military threats from neighboring powers. In 1644, the dynasty was overthrown by a rebellion led by Li Zicheng, which paved the way for the Qing dynasty to take power. Despite its relatively short reign, the Ming dynasty left a lasting impact on Chinese history and culture.

Japan..passage: Japan is an island country in East Asia, located in the northwest Pacific Ocean. The country is home to some of the world's largest and most influential companies, including Toyota, Sony, and Nintendo. Japan is also a major exporter of automobiles, electronics, and machinery. Despite its modernization and economic success, Japan has also faced significant challenges in recent years. The country has struggled with an aging population, declining birth rates, and a shrinking workforce. Japan has also been affected by natural disasters, including earthquakes, tsunamis, and typhoons. Overall, Japan remains a fascinating and complex country, with a rich history and culture, a thriving economy, and a unique place in the world.

Winnie the Pooh..passage: Winnie the Pooh is a fictional character created by English author A. A. Milne. The character first appeared in the book Winnie-the-Pooh (1926) and its sequel The House at Pooh Corner (1928). Milne also included a poem about the bear in the children's verse book When We Were Very Young (1924) and many more in Now We Are Six (1927). All four volumes were illustrated by E. H. Shepard. The Pooh stories have been translated into many languages, including Alexander Lenard's Latin translation, Winnie ille Pu, which was first published in 1958, and, in 1960, became the only Latin book ever to have been featured on The New York Times Best Seller list. In popular film adaptations, Pooh has been voiced by actors Sterling Holloway, Hal Smith, and Jim Cummings in English and Yevgeny Leonov in Russian. He has also been portrayed in theatrical adaptations, including a 2011 West End production and a 2018 Broadway production. Disney's 2018 film Christopher Robin is based on a concept that predates the Disney adaptations, in which an adult Christopher Robin reunites with Pooh and his friends in the Hundred Acre Wood.

The film was directed by Chris Sanders and Dean DeBlois, and features the voices of Daveigh Chase, Chris Sanders, Tia Carrere, David Ogden Stiers, Kevin McDonald, Ving Rhames, Jason Scott Lee, and Zoe Caldwell. The film follows an extraterrestrial creature named Stitch who is adopted by a young Hawaiian girl named Lilo, and the two develop a close bond as they navigate through the challenges of family, friendship, and acceptance. The film was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $273 million worldwide and receiving praise for its unique blend of humor, heart, and science fiction elements. It has since spawned a franchise that includes several sequels, a television series, and various merchandise.

The Walt Disney Company..passage: The Walt Disney Company, commonly known as Disney, is an American diversified multinational mass media and entertainment conglomerate headquartered at the Walt Disney Studios complex in Burbank, California. Disney was originally founded on October 16, 1923, by brothers Walt and Roy O. Disney as the Disney Brothers Cartoon Studio; it also operated under the names The Walt Disney Studio and Walt Disney Productions before officially changing its name to The Walt Disney Company in 1986. The company established itself as a leader in the American animation industry before diversifying into live-action film production, television, and theme parks. Today, Disney's media empire spans a wide range of properties, including movies, television shows, theme parks, merchandise, and more. The company is known for its iconic characters such as Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck, and Goofy, as well as its popular franchises like Star Wars, Marvel, and Pixar. With a market capitalization of over $300 billion, Disney is one of the largest media companies in the world.

Florida..passage: Florida is a state located in the southeastern region of the United States. Tallahassee is the state's capital.

Vatican City..passage: Vatican City, officially known as the Vatican City State, is a landlocked sovereign city-state surrounded by Rome, Italy. It is the smallest independent state in the world by both area and population. The Vatican is an ecclesiastical or sacerdotal-monarchical state ruled by the pope who is the bishop of Rome and head of the Roman Catholic Church. The highest state functionaries are all Catholic clergy of various national origins. Since the return of the popes from Avignon in 1377, they have generally resided at the Apostolic Palace within what is now Vatican City, although at times residing instead in the Quirinal Palace in Rome or elsewhere. Vatican City is distinct from the Holy See, which dates back to early Christianity and is the main episcopal see of 1.2 billion Latin and Eastern Catholic adherents around the globe. The independent city-state, on the other hand, came into existence in 1929 by the Lateran Treaty between the Holy See and Italy, which spoke of it as a new creation, not as a vestige of the much larger Papal States (756–1870), which had previously encompassed much of central Italy. Vatican City is an ecclesiastical or sacerdotal-monarchical state (a type of theocracy) ruled by the pope who is the bishop of Rome and head of the Roman Catholic Church. The highest state functionaries are all Catholic clergy of various national origins. It is the sovereign territory of the Holy See (Sancta Sedes) and the location of the Pope's residence, referred to as the Apostolic Palace. The Popes have generally resided in the area that in 1929 became Vatican City since the return from Avignon in 1377, but have also at times resided in the Quirinal Palace in Rome and elsewhere. Vatican City is also home to the Roman Curia, the central governing body of the Catholic Church. The Vatican City State is not a member of the European Union, but the Holy See is a permanent observer state in the United Nations.

Michelangelo..passage: Michelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni (6 March 1475 – 18 February 1564), known simply as Michelangelo, was an Italian sculptor, painter, architect and poet of the High Renaissance born in the Republic of Florence, who exerted an unparalleled influence on the development of Western art. His artistic versatility was of such a high order that he is often considered a contender for the title of the archetypal Renaissance man, along with his rival and fellow Italian Leonardo da Vinci. Several scholars have described Michelangelo as the greatest artist of his age and even as the greatest artist of all time. A number of his works in painting, sculpture, and architecture rank among the most famous in existence. His output in every field during his long life was prodigious; when the sheer volume of correspondence, sketches, and reminiscences that survive is also taken into account, he is the best-documented artist of the 16th century. Two of his best-known works, the Pietà and David, were sculpted before he turned thirty. Despite holding a low opinion of painting, he also created two of the most influential frescoes in the history of Western art: the scenes from Genesis on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel in Rome, and The Last Judgment on its altar wall. His design of the Laurentian Library pioneered Mannerist architecture. At the age of 74, he succeeded Antonio da Sangallo the Younger as the architect of St. Peter's Basilica. He transformed the plan so that the western end was finished to his design, as was the dome, with some modification, after his death. Michelangelo was unique as the first Western artist whose biography was published while he was alive. In fact, two biographies were published during his lifetime. One of them, by Giorgio Vasari, proposed that he was the pinnacle of all artistic achievement since the beginning of the Renaissance, a viewpoint that continued to have currency in art history for centuries. In his lifetime, Michelangelo was often called Il Divino ("the divine one"). His contemporaries often admired his terribilità—his ability to instil a sense of awe. Attempts by subsequent artists to imitate Michelangelo's impassioned, highly personal style resulted in Mannerism, the next major movement in Western art after the High Renaissance.

Marin County..passage: Marin County is a county located in the San Francisco Bay Area of the U.S. state of California. As of the 2010 census, the population was 252,409. Marin County is well known for its natural beauty, liberal politics, and affluence. In May 2009, Marin County had the fifth highest income per capita in the United States at about $91,480. The county is governed by the Marin County Board of Supervisors. San Quentin Prison is located in the county, as is George Lucas' Skywalker Ranch. Autodesk, the publisher of AutoCAD, is also located there, as well as numerous other high-tech companies. The Marin County Civic Center was designed by Frank Lloyd Wright and draws thousands of visitors a year to guided tours of its arch and atrium design. In 1994, a new county jail facility was embedded into the hillside nearby. Marin County's natural sites include the Muir Woods redwood forest, the Marin Headlands, Stinson Beach, the Point Reyes National Seashore, and Mount Tamalpais. Marin County is also well known for its liberal politics. In 2004, George Bush lost the county by a margin of 4 to 1. Marin County is one of the most Democratic-leaning counties in the United States.

American Society of Civil Engineers..passage: The American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) is a professional organization that represents civil engineers worldwide. Founded in 1852, it is the oldest national engineering society in the United States. The ASCE's mission is to provide essential value to its members, their careers, and the public by developing leadership, advancing technology, advocating lifelong learning, and promoting the profession. The organization has over 150,000 members in 177 countries and is headquartered in Reston, Virginia. The ASCE publishes technical and professional journals, holds conferences and seminars, and provides continuing education opportunities for its members. It also advocates for infrastructure investment and promotes sustainable engineering practices. The ASCE is divided into geographic regions and technical divisions, allowing members to connect with others in their area of expertise. The organization also has a code of ethics that its members are expected to follow, which includes a commitment to protecting public health and safety, maintaining professional integrity, and promoting sustainability.

Joseph Strauss..passage: Joseph Strauss (January 9, 1870 – May 16, 1938) was an American engineer who is best known for his role in the design and construction of the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco, California. Born in Cincinnati, Ohio, Strauss studied engineering at the University of Cincinnati before moving to San Francisco in 1903. He worked as a bridge designer and builder, and in 1917 he proposed a plan for a bridge across the Golden Gate Strait, which was then considered impossible due to the strong currents and high winds in the area. Despite opposition from many quarters, Strauss persisted in his vision and eventually won the support of the city's leaders and the public. He spent the next several years designing and overseeing the construction of the bridge, which was completed in 1937. The Golden Gate Bridge is now considered one of the most iconic landmarks in the United States, and Strauss is remembered as one of the greatest engineers of the 20th century.

Today, the American West is a popular destination for tourists, offering a wide range of outdoor activities, including hiking, camping, skiing, and whitewater rafting. The region is also home to several major cities, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, Denver, and Seattle, which offer a diverse array of cultural attractions and entertainment options. Despite its modernization, the American West remains a symbol of the pioneering spirit and rugged individualism that have come to define the American identity.

Spain..passage: Spain, officially the Kingdom of Spain, is a country in Southwestern Europe with some pockets of territory across the Strait of Gibraltar and the Atlantic Ocean. Its continental European territory is situated on the Iberian Peninsula. Its territory also includes two archipelagos: the Canary Islands off the coast of Africa, and the Balearic Islands in the Mediterranean Sea. The African enclaves of Ceuta, Melilla, and Peñón de Vélez de la Gomera make Spain the only European country to have a physical border with an African country (Morocco). Several small islands in the Alboran Sea are also part of Spanish territory. The country's mainland is bordered to the south and east by the Mediterranean Sea except for a small land boundary with Gibraltar; to the north and northeast by France, Andorra, and the Bay of Biscay; and to the west and northwest by Portugal and the Atlantic Ocean.

Antoni Gaudí..passage: Antoni Gaudí i Cornet (25 June 1852 – 10 June 1926) was a Spanish architect known as the greatest exponent of Catalan Modernism. Gaudí's works have a highly individualized, one-of-a-kind style. Most are located in Barcelona, including his main work, the church of the Sagrada Família. Gaudí's work was influenced by his passions in life: architecture, nature, and religion. He considered every detail of his creations and integrated into his architecture such crafts as ceramics, stained glass, wrought ironwork forging and carpentry. He also introduced new techniques in the treatment of materials, such as trencadís, made of waste ceramic pieces. Under the influence of neo-Gothic art and Oriental techniques, Gaudí became part of the Modernista movement which was reaching its peak in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. His work transcended mainstream Modernisme, culminating in an organic style inspired by natural forms. Gaudí rarely drew detailed plans of his works, instead preferring to create them as three-dimensional scale models and molding the details as he conceived them.

Barcelona..passage: Barcelona is the capital and largest city of Catalonia, an autonomous community in northeastern Spain. It is the second most populous municipality in Spain and the sixth most populous urban area in the European Union. Barcelona is one of the world's leading tourist, economic, trade fair and cultural centers, and its influence in commerce, education, entertainment, media, fashion, science, and the arts all contribute to its status as one of the world's major global cities. It is a major cultural and economic center in southwestern Europe, 24th in the world (before Zürich, after Frankfurt) and a financial center. In 2008 it was the fourth most economically powerful city by GDP in the European Union and 35th in the world with GDP amounting to €177 billion. In 2012 Barcelona had a GDP of $170 billion; it is leading Spain in both employment rate and GDP per capita change. In 2009 the city was ranked Europe's third and one of the world's most successful as a city brand. In the same year the city was ranked Europe's fourth best city for business and fastest improving European city, with growth improved by 17% per year, and the city has been experiencing strong and renewed growth for the past three years. Since 2011 Barcelona has been a leading smart city in Europe.

Alcazaba..passage: Alcazaba is a term used in Spanish to refer to a fortified palace or citadel. The term is derived from the Arabic word al-qasbah, which means "citadel" or "fortress". The Alcazaba was a common feature of Islamic architecture in Spain during the Middle Ages, and many examples of these structures can still be seen today. One of the most famous examples of an Alcazaba is the Alhambra in Granada, Spain. This massive fortress and palace complex was built by the Moors in the 13th and 14th centuries and is considered one of the finest examples of Islamic architecture in the world. The Alhambra features a series of interconnected palaces, courtyards, and gardens, all surrounded by high walls and towers. Other notable examples of Alcazabas in Spain include the Alcazaba of Malaga, the Alcazaba of Almeria, and the Alcazaba of Antequera. These structures were built during the same period as the Alhambra and feature similar architectural styles and design elements. Today, many of these Alcazabas have been restored and are open to the public as museums or tourist attractions. Visitors can explore the intricate mosaics, ornate carvings, and stunning views from the towers and ramparts of these ancient fortresses, gaining a deeper understanding of the rich history and culture of Spain.

Washington Irving..passage: Washington Irving (April 3, 1783 – November 28, 1859) was an American author, essayist, biographer, historian, and diplomat of the early 19th century. He is best known for his short stories "Rip Van Winkle" (1819) and "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow" (1820), both of which appear in his collection, The Sketch Book of Geoffrey Crayon, Gent. Irving served as the U.S. ambassador to Spain from 1842 to 1846. He made his literary debut in 1802 with a series of observational letters to the Morning Chronicle, written under the pseudonym Jonathan Oldstyle. After moving to England for the family business in 1815, he achieved international fame with the publication of The Sketch Book in 1819–20. He continued to publish regularly throughout his life, and he served as a cultural ambassador for the United States in Europe. He was also an advocate for the preservation of the Hudson River Valley, and he served as the first president of the Astor Library in New York City.

Qin Shi Huang..passage: Qin Shi Huang was the first emperor of a unified China and ruled from 221 BC to 210 BC. He is known for his ruthless tactics in unifying the warring states of China and for his massive construction projects, including the Great Wall of China. Qin Shi Huang also standardized weights and measures, currency, and the written language, which helped to unify the country. He is also credited with the creation of the Terracotta Army, a collection of life-sized clay soldiers that were buried with him to protect him in the afterlife. Despite his accomplishments, Qin Shi Huang was also known for his cruelty and paranoia, and he ordered the burning of books and the burying of scholars who opposed him. His reign ended with his death in 210 BC, and his dynasty was overthrown just a few years later. However, his legacy as a unifier of China and a builder of monumental structures has endured to this day.

Nevada..passage: Nevada is a state in the Western United States. It is bordered by Oregon to the northwest, Idaho to the northeast, California to the west, Arizona to the southeast, and Utah to the east. Nevada is the 7th most extensive, the 19th least populous, but the 9th least densely populated of the U.S. states. Nearly three-quarters of Nevada's people live in Clark County, which contains the Las Vegas–Paradise metropolitan area, including three of the state's four largest incorporated cities. Nevada's capital is Carson City. Nevada is officially known as the "Silver State" because of the importance of silver to its history and economy. It is also known as the "Battle Born State" because it achieved statehood during the Civil War (the words "Battle Born" also appear on the state flag); as the "Sagebrush State", for the native plant of the same name; and as the "Sage-hen State".

The Strip..passage: The Strip is a stretch of Las Vegas Boulevard South in Clark County, Nevada, internationally known for its concentration of resort hotels and casinos along its route. The Strip is approximately 4.2 miles (6.8 km) in length, located immediately south of the Las Vegas city limits in the unincorporated towns of Paradise and Winchester. Fifteen of the world's 25 largest hotels by room count are on the Strip, with a total of over 62,000 rooms. One of the most visible aspects of Las Vegas' cityscape is its use of dramatic architecture and lights. Las Vegas..passage: Las Vegas is a city in the state of Nevada, located in the United States. It is known for its vibrant nightlife, luxurious hotels and casinos, and world-class entertainment. The city is situated in the Mojave Desert and is surrounded by mountains, making it a popular destination for outdoor enthusiasts as well. Las Vegas was originally founded in 1905 as a small railroad town, but it quickly grew into a bustling city thanks to the legalization of gambling in 1931. Today, the city is home to some of the largest and most extravagant casinos in the world, including the Bellagio, the Venetian, and the MGM Grand. In addition to its casinos, Las Vegas is also known for its entertainment industry. The city is home to numerous theaters, concert venues, and nightclubs, and is a popular destination for top performers from around the world. Some of the most famous shows in Las Vegas include Cirque du Soleil, Blue Man Group, and Penn & Teller. Despite its reputation as a party city, Las Vegas also has a rich cultural history. The city is home to several museums and art galleries, including the Neon Museum, which showcases the city's iconic neon signs, and the Mob Museum, which explores the history of organized crime in Las Vegas. Overall, Las Vegas is a city that offers something for everyone. Whether you're looking to gamble, see a show, or explore the great outdoors, this vibrant city is sure to leave a lasting impression.

Betty Willis..passage: Betty Willis (May 18, 1921 – April 19, 2015) was an American graphic designer. She is best known for designing the "Welcome to Fabulous Las Vegas" sign, which has become an iconic symbol of the city. Willis was born in Overton, Nevada and grew up in Las Vegas. She attended the University of Nevada, Reno and the Art Institute of Pittsburgh. After working as a commercial artist in Los Angeles, Willis returned to Las Vegas in 1952 and opened her own design firm. In 1959, she was commissioned by the local Chamber of Commerce to design a sign that would welcome visitors to the city. The resulting design, featuring a stylized image of a cowboy and the words "Welcome to Fabulous Las Vegas," has become one of the most recognizable landmarks in the United States. Willis continued to work as a graphic designer in Las Vegas until her retirement in 1985. She died in 2015 at the age of 93.

Colosseum..passage: The Colosseum, also known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an oval amphitheatre in the centre of Rome, Italy. Built of travertine, tuff, and brick-faced concrete, it is the largest amphitheatre ever built. The Colosseum is situated just east of the Roman Forum. Construction began under the emperor Vespasian in AD 72 and was completed in AD 80 under his successor and heir, Titus. Further modifications were made during the reign of Domitian (81–96). These three emperors are known as the Flavian dynasty, and the amphitheatre was named in Latin for its association with their family name (Flavius). The Colosseum could hold, it is estimated, between 50,000 and 80,000 spectators, having an average audience of some 65,000; it was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles such as mock sea battles (for only a short time as the hypogeum was soon filled in with mechanisms to support the other activities), animal hunts, executions, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas based on Classical mythology. The building ceased to be used for entertainment in the early medieval era. It was later reused for such purposes as housing, workshops, quarters for a religious order, a fortress, a quarry, and a Christian shrine. Although partially ruined because of damage caused by earthquakes and stone-robbers, the Colosseum is still an iconic symbol of Imperial Rome and is listed as one of the New7Wonders of the World. It is one of Rome's most popular tourist attractions and also has links to the Roman Catholic Church, as each Good Friday the Pope leads a torchlit "Way of the Cross" procession that starts in the area around the Colosseum.

qae_pairs.explanation: The passage states that Versace has dressed some of the world's most famous celebrities, including Madonna, Jennifer Lopez, and Lady Gaga. Therefore, Lady Gaga is a famous celebrity who has been dressed by Versace.

qae_pairs.explanation: Versace has luxury hotels and resorts in Dubai and Australia.
